Authors: Dondio P.; Almo A.; Amaral M.; Tibebe E.; Rocha M.; Brennan A.
Author full names: Dondio, Pierpaolo (15020266500); Almo, André (57211075659); Amaral, Maíra (58771701500); Tibebe, Ephrem (57724678100); Rocha, Mariana (57205182840); Brennan, Attracta (7102229392)
Title: Not (Only) a Matter of Position: Player Traits Which Influence the Experience with the Leaderboard in a Digital Maths Game
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: School of Computer Science, Technological University Dublin, Dublin, Ireland; Computer Science Department, University of Galway, Galway, Ireland
Authors with affiliations: Dondio P., School of Computer Science, Technological University Dublin, Dublin, Ireland; Almo A., School of Computer Science, Technological University Dublin, Dublin, Ireland; Amaral M., School of Computer Science, Technological University Dublin, Dublin, Ireland; Tibebe E., School of Computer Science, Technological University Dublin, Dublin, Ireland; Rocha M., School of Computer Science, Technological University Dublin, Dublin, Ireland; Brennan A., Computer Science Department, University of Galway, Galway, Ireland
Abstract: Leaderboards have often been shown to increase engagement and motivation in digital serious games, supporting better learning outcomes and positively affecting players’ game experience. However, few studies show how the player’s position on the leaderboard can be a demotivating factor and how the presence of a leaderboard can increase competition and social pressure on players to the point of hindering their game experience. In examining the relationship between a leaderboard and the player’s game experience, we sought to identify the significant factors influencing whether or not a player liked the presence of a leaderboard in a digital maths game. We conducted an experimental study involving 434 Irish primary school children who participated in a 6-week digital game-based learning (DGBL) programme playing the game Seven Spells, which included a game leaderboard. Results indicated that the players’ enjoyment of the leaderboard depended not only on their in-game performance (i.e. their position on the leaderboard), but also on their level of maths anxiety and how much they enjoyed different play modes such as playing versus a classmate or playing alone. These results suggest that game designers should consider the non-cognitive traits of players when deciding on the inclusion of a leaderboard in a digital maths game, in order to mitigate its potential negative effects on the players’ game experience. © 2024, The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG.
Author Keywords: game design; game-based learning; maths anxiety
Index Keywords: Game design; Digital game-based learning; Game design; Game experience; Game-based Learning; Learning outcome; Learning projects; Math anxiety; Player's enjoyments; Primary school children; Social pressures; Serious games

Title: Application of a Serious Game for Emotion Elicitation Under Socio-Economic and Trust Based Decision-Making Scenarios for Autistic Adolescents
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Queen Mary University of London, Mile End Road, Bethnal Green, London, E1 4NS, United Kingdom; University of Genoa, Via All’Opera Pia, 15, Genoa, 16145, Italy; Piccolo Cottolengo Genovese di Don Orione, Via Benvenuto Cellini 22, Genova, 16143, Italy; Rehab Technologies Lab, Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia, Via Morego, 30, Genoa, 16163, Italy

Abstract: The relationship between decision-making and emotions has been extensively studied in both theoretical and empirical research. Game Theory-based paradigms utilizing socio-economic and trust-based contexts have been established to elicit specific emotional responses in autistic individuals. Serious games, incorporating cohesive storylines and multiple interactions within these contexts, can serve as engaging tools for emotion elicitation in autistic individuals. As autistic adolescents tend to show higher engagement with games, we aimed to investigate applicability in this population. To achieve this, we developed a mobile serious game that combines four socio-economic and trust-based game paradigms, aiming to evoke specific emotions of varying intensities during different interactions. This paper presents the outcomes of a preliminary experiment involving thirteen participants. The results show that the game’s designed interactions successfully elicited emotional responses aligning with the expectations derived from literature in non-game applications. © 2024, The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG.

Title: Design Gamification Strategies in a Digital Learning Environment: The Impact on Students
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Dipartimento di Biotecnologie Molecolari e Scienze per la Salute, Università di Torino, Via Nizza, 52, TO, Turin, 10126, Italy; Dipartimento di Informatica, Università di Torino, Corso Svizzera, 185, TO, Turin, 10149, Italy

Abstract: Over the past few decades, gamification has become increasingly popular and widely used to motivate and engage learners in the digital age. Based on gamification strategies that have been shown to be useful in literature, we wondered how they can be developed in the Digital Learning Environment of the Digital Math Training project. To understand the impact and effectiveness of our implemented gamification strategies in the DLE, we considered the students’ answers, from grade 9th to 13th, to initial and final questionnaire. The results show which of the strategies implemented were most appreciated by the DMT students and which were found to be effective in stimulating their motivation, especially for some categories of students. © 2024, The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG.
Author Keywords: Digital Learning Environment; Gamification Design Principles; Gamification Strategies
Index Keywords: Computer aided instruction; E-learning; Design Principles; Digital age; Digital learning environment; Gamification; Gamification design principle; Gamification strategy; Training program; Students
Funding Details: Digital Math Training; Fondazione CRT; Università degli Studi di Torino, UNITO
Funding Texts: The context of the research is the Digital Math Training (DMT) project funded by the Fondazione CRT within the Diderot Project and organized by the University of Turin. The core part of the project is the online training attended by the most skilled or motivated upper secondary school students selected by their teachers after the “in-presence training” phase. Those students are enrolled in the DLE of DMT project, which hosts several activities [12]. The technological component of the DLE includes a Moodle platform integrated with an Advanced Computing Environment, a tool designed for learning STEM disciplines [13]. Previous editions, like the ninth current one, were characterized by a challenge where students competed for about 25 final prizes [14]. In the current one we decided to intensify the gamified approach aiming to increase engagement and participation in the DMT online training and trying to reduce the dropout rate compared to previous editions, which had a fairly high dropout rate [13].

Title: Serious Games as Emerging E-Health Interventions: Design of an Exergame for the SMILER Project
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)

Abstract: This paper outlines the design and implementation of an exergame developed under the strategic Italian CNR project SMILER (Serious gaMes in chILdren with nEurological or Respiratory disorders). The project aims at investigating how Serious Games (SG) can enhance the health conditions of young people with chronic diseases, specifically targeting two categories: individuals with Down Syndrome and those with Asthma. The SG employs a narrative strategy within an immersive, interactive setup. The child’s movements are captured and translated into actions performed by an in-game avatar, who is central to the story. Additionally, a wristband continuously monitors the child’s physiological data, ensuring they remain within the aerobic zone. In this document, the game’s architectural modules and design decisions are described, along with introducing the experimental plan to explore the game’s impact on transcriptome profiling (CTRA) gene patterns and neuropsychological outcomes through an upcoming pilot study. © The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2025.

Authors: Hawthorn S.; Jesus R.; Baptista M.A.
Author full names: Hawthorn, Steven (57226267598); Jesus, Rui (23012170100); Baptista, Maria Ana (7102934075)
Title: A Reusable Serious Game Model for Natural Hazard Risk Communication: Evaluation of a Tsunami-Focused Case Study
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Universidade NOVA de Lisboa, Lisbon, 1099-085, Portugal; ISEL, Instituto Politécnico de Lisboa, Lisbon, 1959-007, Portugal; Instituto Dom Luiz, Faculdade de Ciências da Universidade de Lisboa, Lisbon, 1746-016, Portugal
Authors with affiliations: Hawthorn S., Universidade NOVA de Lisboa, Lisbon, 1099-085, Portugal; Jesus R., ISEL, Instituto Politécnico de Lisboa, Lisbon, 1959-007, Portugal; Baptista M.A., Instituto Dom Luiz, Faculdade de Ciências da Universidade de Lisboa, Lisbon, 1746-016, Portugal
Abstract: This paper outlines the challenges around communicating natural hazard risk to children, due to the nature and concept of risk. It utilizes trusted disaster risk reduction advice to form the learning objectives of a serious game prototype for tsunami hazard. The study proposes an activity model that could form the basis of a game applicable to twelve different natural hazard scenarios thereby reducing resource input and reaching a significant number of learners in the formal education system. Evaluation of the prototype using an attitudinal survey suggests an adventure role playing game centered on challenges which use risk information is a viable concept for a serious game for communicating natural hazard risk. © 2024, The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG.

Authors: Thoma G.; Moeller K.; Ninaus M.; Bahnmueller J.
Author full names: Thoma, Georgios (58024126000); Moeller, Korbinian (23019055400); Ninaus, Manuel (55797096600); Bahnmueller, Julia (55878359100)
Title: Collectible Content – Towards a Modular Ecosystem of Intrinsically Integrated Gameplay: The Case of Fractions
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Department of Mathematics Education, Loughborough University, Loughborough, United Kingdom; LEAD Graduate School and Research Network, University of Tübingen, Tübingen, Germany; Leibniz-Institut Fuer Wissensmedien, Tübingen, Germany; Institute of Psychology, University of Graz, Graz, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Thoma G., Department of Mathematics Education, Loughborough University, Loughborough, United Kingdom; Moeller K., Department of Mathematics Education, Loughborough University, Loughborough, United Kingdom, LEAD Graduate School and Research Network, University of Tübingen, Tübingen, Germany, Leibniz-Institut Fuer Wissensmedien, Tübingen, Germany; Ninaus M., LEAD Graduate School and Research Network, University of Tübingen, Tübingen, Germany, Institute of Psychology, University of Graz, Graz, Austria; Bahnmueller J., Department of Mathematics Education, Loughborough University, Loughborough, United Kingdom, LEAD Graduate School and Research Network, University of Tübingen, Tübingen, Germany
Abstract: Designing a good game is hard. Designing a learning game might be even harder as it requires engaging game elements to be aligned with the respective learning content. However, when this alignment is successful—referred to as intrinsic integration—games become effective tools for learning. In this article, the idea of collectible content is introduced as one way to achieve or make more pervasive use of intrinsic integration to support learning. Similar to an in-game currency system, learning content may be incorporated as in-game collectibles whose collection and manipulation are central aspects of gameplay. To substantiate the beneficial effects of collectible content, it is repeatedly presented, explored, and analyzed through various gameplay tasks. Through its characteristics of duality, consistency, and uniqueness/uniformity, collectible content evolves and adapts offering continuous opportunities for the development of conceptual understanding of the respective content—along with practice of procedures and acquisition of fact knowledge for the tasks at hand. To illustrate the idea and highlight affordances and potential impact of intrinsic integration, we present a prototype design of a fraction learning game to showcase a modular ecosystem focused on collectible content gameplay. © 2024, The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG.

Authors: Merilampi S.; Jyräkoski T.; Poberznik A.; Karttunen N.; Seessalo T.; Virkki J.; Lipping T.
Author full names: Merilampi, Sari (25638629500); Jyräkoski, Taina (57223993524); Poberznik, Anja (57208104698); Karttunen, Nina (58515673900); Seessalo, Toni (58771727600); Virkki, Johanna (24722238800); Lipping, Tarmo (6603138618)
Title: Gamified Wearable EEG Technology to Support Controlling of Cognitive Load After Brain Injury
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Satakunta University of Applied Sciences, Pori, Finland; Faculty of Information Technology and Communication Sciences, Tampere University, Pori, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Merilampi S., Satakunta University of Applied Sciences, Pori, Finland; Jyräkoski T., Satakunta University of Applied Sciences, Pori, Finland; Poberznik A., Satakunta University of Applied Sciences, Pori, Finland; Karttunen N., Satakunta University of Applied Sciences, Pori, Finland; Seessalo T., Satakunta University of Applied Sciences, Pori, Finland; Virkki J., Faculty of Information Technology and Communication Sciences, Tampere University, Pori, Finland; Lipping T., Faculty of Information Technology and Communication Sciences, Tampere University, Pori, Finland
Abstract: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) results from an injury to the head. Depending on the severity of the injury and the affected regions of the brain, consequences vary a lot. Apart from physical challenges, a person with TBI may have various cognitive deficits, which affect the cognitive load of the person in different situations. The paper presents an early paper prototype for a wearable cognitive load measurement device design using biomarkers from an electroencephalogram (EEG). The paper discusses how the rehabilitation and daily tasks could be adjusted and optimized for individuals’ needs by using such a cognitive load measurement tool. Designing this kind of system requires skills from various disciplines. Thus, the early product design was created in a multidisciplinary workshop. As everyday EEG-based tools are still in their early development phase, it is very important to pay a lot of attention to technical development. However, in order to facilitate the implementation of such technology, it is also crucial to concentrate on easy-to-wear, user-friendly, and fashionable product design. © 2024, The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG.

Authors: Rosa M.; Lopes S.; Martins N.; Lacomba-Arnau E.
Author full names: Rosa, Marlene (55924760400); Lopes, Susana (57937243500); Martins, Natália (58283961800); Lacomba-Arnau, Elena (59325230000)
Title: Games as a Non-pharmacology Therapy for Chronic Pain – A Mixed Method Pilot Study in Older People
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: ciTechCare - Center for Innovative Care and Health Technology School of Health Sciences (ESSLei), Leiria, Portugal; University of Salamanca, Salamanca, Spain; Departament de Psicologia, Sociologia i Treball Social, Universitat de Lleida, Lleida, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Rosa M., ciTechCare - Center for Innovative Care and Health Technology School of Health Sciences (ESSLei), Leiria, Portugal; Lopes S., ciTechCare - Center for Innovative Care and Health Technology School of Health Sciences (ESSLei), Leiria, Portugal, University of Salamanca, Salamanca, Spain; Martins N., ciTechCare - Center for Innovative Care and Health Technology School of Health Sciences (ESSLei), Leiria, Portugal; Lacomba-Arnau E., Departament de Psicologia, Sociologia i Treball Social, Universitat de Lleida, Lleida, Spain
Abstract: This pilot study investigates the use of games as a non-pharmacological therapy for chronic pain in older adults. A group of institutionalized older adults experiencing persistent pain, without cognitive impairment, was recruited. Sociodemographic data were collected, and pain intensity was measured using the Visual Analogue Pain Scale (VAS) before and after a 20-min game-based intervention. Post-intervention, participants were interviewed about their personal experiences with the game. The “Tree Game,” a giant floorboard game (Agilidades.pt), was selected for its unique properties conducive to this study (e.g., multi-stimuli approach). Significant differences in VAS scores before and after the Tree Game intervention were analyzed using the Wilcoxon test. Qualitative analysis of participants’ feedback was also conducted. Results indicated that seventeen participants reported a reduction in pain following the game-based intervention (Group 1). The VAS scores demonstrated significant improvement in pain perception post-intervention (median = 4.50 vs. 3.00; P = 0.005). Six themes emerged from the qualitative analysis, describing the “Tree Game” as a playful and engaging experience that positively influenced pain perception. © The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2025.

Author full names: Baberowski, David (57557413800); Leonhardt, Thiemo (35229590100); Buchner, Josef (57203548193); Bergner, Nadine (54957809700)
Title: Comparing Interaction Modalities in VR Serious Games: A Study on Presence and Enjoyment
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: TU Dresden University of Technology, Dresden, Germany; RWTH Aachen University, Aachen, Germany; St.Gallen University of Teacher Education, St. Gallen, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Baberowski D., TU Dresden University of Technology, Dresden, Germany; Leonhardt T., RWTH Aachen University, Aachen, Germany; Buchner J., St.Gallen University of Teacher Education, St. Gallen, Switzerland; Bergner N., RWTH Aachen University, Aachen, Germany
Abstract: This study investigates the impact of different interaction modalities on presence and enjoyment in VR serious games, focusing on two versions of a game designed to teach routing and network concepts. One version employs a catch and throw (CT) interaction, while the other uses a walk and place (WP) interaction. Conducted as a between-subject design field study with secondary school students, both versions achieved similar levels of presence and enjoyment among participants, with no significant differences. Nevertheless, a sensitivity analysis of the results indicates that the type of interaction has a minimal impact on the target variables of enjoyment and presence in the study, which are crucial for VR serious games. © The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2025.

Authors: Dever D.A.; Wiedbusch M.; Park S.; Llinas A.; Lester J.; Azevedo R.
Author full names: Dever, Daryn A. (57200824887); Wiedbusch, Megan (57201006499); Park, Saerok (58771517900); Llinas, Andrea (58771694000); Lester, James (57203179695); Azevedo, Roger (18036509700)
Title: Assessing the Complexity of Gaming Mechanics During Science Learning
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: University of Central Florida, Orlando, 32828, FL, United States; North Carolina State University, Raleigh, 27695, NC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dever D.A., University of Central Florida, Orlando, 32828, FL, United States; Wiedbusch M., University of Central Florida, Orlando, 32828, FL, United States; Park S., University of Central Florida, Orlando, 32828, FL, United States; Llinas A., University of Central Florida, Orlando, 32828, FL, United States; Lester J., North Carolina State University, Raleigh, 27695, NC, United States; Azevedo R., University of Central Florida, Orlando, 32828, FL, United States
Abstract: Game-based learning environments (GBLEs) incorporate game mechanics, i.e., learning and assessment mechanics, to increase domain knowledge while maintaining learner engagement. Although GBLEs have been developed to improve science learning, learners have attained lower science achievement scores over the past decade as they progress through school. As such, there is a need to better understand how learners use game mechanics as they learn about science content. This study aimed to understand how learners generally use and transition between learning and assessment mechanics while learning about science with a GBLE and how those transitions were related to learning outcomes (i.e., learning gains, game success). High-school students (N = 137) were recruited to play Crystal Island, a GBLE about microbiology. Results found that participants used static learning mechanics (e.g., virtual books about microbiology) most often, followed by game and content assessment mechanics, and lastly followed by aid and dynamic learning mechanics. Further results found that several sequential transition probabilities were related to lower learning outcomes with a few transitions positively relating to game completion success. Findings from this study also show that the type of game mechanic, as well as the direction of transitions across game mechanics significantly relate to learning outcomes. These findings provide insights into how to develop scaffolding techniques for improving science learning outcomes. © 2024, The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG.

Authors: Albertsson V.; Hibbs P.; Farkas C.; Ren Q.; Zaidi A.; Marroquim R.; Eisemann E.; Bidarra R.
Author full names: Albertsson, Vincent (59500128000); Hibbs, Patrick (59500935900); Farkas, Csanád (59500402800); Ren, Qinxin (59500265100); Zaidi, Amir (57215971122); Marroquim, Ricardo (8964606800); Eisemann, Elmar (35304781200); Bidarra, Rafael (6602846970)
Title: Puzzle Playground – Teaching VR Interactions Through a Puzzle Game
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Delft University of Technology, Delft, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Albertsson V., Delft University of Technology, Delft, Netherlands; Hibbs P., Delft University of Technology, Delft, Netherlands; Farkas C., Delft University of Technology, Delft, Netherlands; Ren Q., Delft University of Technology, Delft, Netherlands; Zaidi A., Delft University of Technology, Delft, Netherlands; Marroquim R., Delft University of Technology, Delft, Netherlands; Eisemann E., Delft University of Technology, Delft, Netherlands; Bidarra R., Delft University of Technology, Delft, Netherlands
Abstract: In recent years, it has become clear that modern education is not currently equipped with the proper tools to fully support remote teaching. Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to make remote education viable in the future. Nevertheless, many teachers and students lack experience and familiarity with this technology, which poses a challenge to its adoption in education. In this paper, we introduce Puzzle Playground, a game that builds familiarity with VR by teaching object interactions through puzzles in an interactive experience tailored for educators. Players gradually learn VR interactions by completing various puzzle levels. A preliminary user study indicated that people who learned with Puzzle Playground grasped VR interactions faster than those who learned with printed or visual methods. © The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2025.

Authors: Wang A.I.
Author full names: Wang, Alf Inge (7404619969)
Title: Use of Game Design and Game Elements in Serious Project Management Games
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Trondheim, N7491, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Wang A.I., Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Trondheim, N7491, Norway
Abstract: Using serious games to teach project management is a logical choice, as it al-lows students to practice skills without facing real-world economic or human consequences. These games offer a realistic learning environment where players can experiment with different ideas and retry projects after failure. Additionally, game-based learning enhances learning outcomes, motivation, and engagement. However, to fully realize these benefits, serious games must incorporate established game design principles and elements. This paper presents a literature review examining how well existing project management games apply such principles. The study analyzes 64 games using Malone’s Taxonomy for Intrinsic Motivation, the GameFlow framework, eight reward systems, and other recognized game design elements. © The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2025.

Title: Development of a Simulation to Aid Navigation in First Year CS Students
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: School of Arts, English & Languages Queen’s University Belfast, Belfast, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Woods C., School of Arts, English & Languages Queen’s University Belfast, Belfast, United Kingdom; Tasker-Lynch A., School of Arts, English & Languages Queen’s University Belfast, Belfast, United Kingdom; Le Seelleur J., School of Arts, English & Languages Queen’s University Belfast, Belfast, United Kingdom; McBride S., School of Arts, English & Languages Queen’s University Belfast, Belfast, United Kingdom; Gilbride R., School of Arts, English & Languages Queen’s University Belfast, Belfast, United Kingdom; Brice D., School of Arts, English & Languages Queen’s University Belfast, Belfast, United Kingdom; Lydon D., School of Arts, English & Languages Queen’s University Belfast, Belfast, United Kingdom
Abstract: Transferring to university for the first time can be an exciting and potentially overwhelming experience for students, particularly those from less privileged backgrounds or those prone to anxiety. These students can sometimes face difficulties integrating into campus life leading to increased access to disability services. This case study details the development and testing of simulation of the Computer Science building at Queen’s University Belfast with the aim of aiding students in their transition to university. © The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2025.

Authors: Hovey C.; Jakubowicz S.
Author full names: Hovey, Chris (57203970830); Jakubowicz, Sara (59403828800)
Title: Motion Design for Emotion Design
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: New York University, New York, 10012, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hovey C., New York University, New York, 10012, NY, United States; Jakubowicz S., New York University, New York, 10012, NY, United States
Abstract: When designing learning experiences, there is evidence that affective features can improve learning. This paper explores the question of how spatial movements of NPCs impact a player’s emotions in an executive function VR game. In two studies, NPC movement approaching players significantly increased arousal when compared to static distance movements. Though EF was not significantly improved following gameplay, a more challenging and adaptive level design may elicit the desired effect. © The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2025.

Authors: Meshcheryakova A.O.; Hemmert F.
Author full names: Meshcheryakova, Anna O. (58238056900); Hemmert, Fabian (25723357300)
Title: Making Games to Make Futures: Playfully Co-designing Games for Civic Learning and Thinking About Futures
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: University of Wuppertal, Gaußstr. 20, Wuppertal, 42119, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Meshcheryakova A.O., University of Wuppertal, Gaußstr. 20, Wuppertal, 42119, Germany; Hemmert F., University of Wuppertal, Gaußstr. 20, Wuppertal, 42119, Germany
Abstract: This paper reports on a co-design workshop conducted to examine how co-designing board games could be conceptualised as an activity for supporting people in critical engagement with potential futures and civic learning. We follow aresearch-through-design approach to investigate how such formats may be designed and used to facilitate creative and collaborative engagement with futures. Thereby, we attempt to position the design activity itself as playful and explore how the idea of how playing and engaging in experiments with prototypes could be seen as making. We reflect on both the workshop blueprint and overall workshop outcomes, exploring to what extent the approaches of criticality, making and play can be balanced, and how they may contribute to supporting workshop participants in engaging with futures in a context of civic learning. © The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2025.

Authors: Koivisto A.; Merilampi S.; Marković D.; Virkki J.; Leino M.
Author full names: Koivisto, Antti (7007009119); Merilampi, Sari (25638629500); Marković, Darija (25626705900); Virkki, Johanna (24722238800); Leino, Mirka (55367837300)
Title: Game-Based Teaching Scenarios in Upper Secondary Mathematics Teaching – European User Experiences
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: RoboAI Research and Development Centre/Faculty of Technology, Satakunta University of Applied Sciences, Pori, 28130, Finland; School of Applied Mathematics and Computer Science, Josip Juraj Strossmayer University of Osijek, Osijek, 31000, Croatia; Tampere Institute for Advanced Study/Faculty of Information Technology and Communication Sciences, Tampere University, Tampere, 33720, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Koivisto A., RoboAI Research and Development Centre/Faculty of Technology, Satakunta University of Applied Sciences, Pori, 28130, Finland; Merilampi S., RoboAI Research and Development Centre/Faculty of Technology, Satakunta University of Applied Sciences, Pori, 28130, Finland; Marković D., School of Applied Mathematics and Computer Science, Josip Juraj Strossmayer University of Osijek, Osijek, 31000, Croatia; Virkki J., Tampere Institute for Advanced Study/Faculty of Information Technology and Communication Sciences, Tampere University, Tampere, 33720, Finland; Leino M., RoboAI Research and Development Centre/Faculty of Technology, Satakunta University of Applied Sciences, Pori, 28130, Finland
Abstract: Research shows that digital games can engage students in mathematics and enhance their performance. While mathematics teachers see “maths games” as useful tools, their lack of knowledge about teaching with such games as well as shortage of appropriate games for teaching upper secondary school mathematics prevents the full potential of game-based teaching. This study presents GeomWiz, a gamified geometry quiz, for learning geometry in upper secondary schools as well as two teaching scenarios for using it in teaching. A student user experience study was carried out in three European countries in which teachers piloted GeomWiz and the teaching scenarios. Based on the results, game-based learning with game contents that matches the learning objectives is suitable for geometry teaching in upper secondary schools. Teaching scenarios assist the inclusion of the game into teaching. © 2024, The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG.

Authors: Li Z.; Jessica S.
Author full names: Li, Zhixin (58296271400); Jessica, Sharon (58771670300)
Title: eKinomy: Designing a Serious Game to Promote Economic Decision-Making Skills from Elementary Level
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, 48014, MI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Li Z., University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, 48014, MI, United States; Jessica S., University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, 48014, MI, United States
Abstract: Serious games are designed to provide purposeful and engaging learning experiences, fostering knowledge acquisition and skills development. They hold the potential to simplify complex theories and concepts, making them easily comprehensible for learners. While the versatility and effectiveness of serious games provide immersive experiences in complex subject matter areas, such as STEM subjects, healthcare, environment science, etc., the integration of serious games into K-12 economic education, particularly for enhancing decision-making skills, remains limited. This paper proposes a work-in-progress role-play simulation serious game design with the theme of international trade designed for grades 5–8 to enact roles of producers, importers, and exporters as well as develop economic decision-making strategies. The paper begins by discussing the necessity of serious games in K-12 economic education. Next, the paper elucidates the design process employed in creating the serious game “eKinomy” and embedding the simulation and role-play elements into it. We outline the steps taken to ensure that the game aligns with the learning objectives of economic education while providing an engaging and immersive experience for learners. © 2024, The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG.

Authors: Pereira N.; Ferreira P.; Francisco S.; Veiga Simão A.M.
Author full names: Pereira, Nádia (57158847600); Ferreira, Paula (56293098000); Francisco, Sofia (56423514100); Veiga Simão, Ana Margarida (54974120700)
Title: Pro(f)Social: A Serious Game to Counter Cyberbullying
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Faculdade de Psicologia, CICPSI, Universidade de Lisboa, Lisbon, Portugal
Authors with affiliations: Pereira N., Faculdade de Psicologia, CICPSI, Universidade de Lisboa, Lisbon, Portugal; Ferreira P., Faculdade de Psicologia, CICPSI, Universidade de Lisboa, Lisbon, Portugal; Francisco S., Faculdade de Psicologia, CICPSI, Universidade de Lisboa, Lisbon, Portugal; Veiga Simão A.M., Faculdade de Psicologia, CICPSI, Universidade de Lisboa, Lisbon, Portugal
Abstract: This study proposes to present the design and face validity of a serious game prototype, Pro(f)Social, as part of a blended learning teacher training program based on social-emotional ethical learning to promote pro-social behavior and well-being among children, through changes in teachers’ emotion regulation and moral involvement with cyberbullying and their social-emotional competence to deal with the phenomenon. Teachers are often unaware of aggressive acts among their students, and even when they are, many consider that they are not responsible for resolving cyberbullying issues. Therefore, it is fundamental to develop resources based on human-machine collaboration to attain several milestones in designing serious games to prevent and intervene in cyberbullying by providing teachers with know-how through interactive training with artificial intelligence. The game presented, along with its face validity (n = 290 units for content analysis), offer technology professionals the necessary knowledge to develop future interventions to counter cyberbullying. © 2024, The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG.

Authors: Celik P.
Author full names: Celik, Pelin (58771618900)
Title: Haptic Recording Experience: The Iceberg Model as a Serious Game for Decision Making in Systemic Design Oriented Leadership (SDOL)
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Hochschule Für Technik Und Wirtschaft, Wilhelminenhofstr. 75 A, Berlin, 12459, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Celik P., Hochschule Für Technik Und Wirtschaft, Wilhelminenhofstr. 75 A, Berlin, 12459, Germany
Abstract: The Iceberg Model, derived from Systems Thinking, is one of the powerful methods for understanding the hidden dynamics and complexities that influence decision making. By examining the various layers of the iceberg metaphorically, one can gain a deeper understanding of the interconnectedness and interdependencies within systems, enabling to make more informed and connected decisions and foster sustainable change in a complex world. By applying the Iceberg Model in the context of serious games, Systemic Design Oriented Leadership (SDOL) in particular could gain a holistic understanding of the hidden dynamics that determine behaviour and outcomes within their organizations. A serious game of this nature has the capacity to augment a leadership learning culture that fosters the investigation of cognitive frameworks, the interrogation of presumptions, and the cultivation of critical thinking. Through dialogue and reflection, SDOL could surface underlying beliefs and values. SDOLthat embraces the gamification of the Iceberg Model might effectively drive sustainable change in a playful manner. By focusing the gameplay on levels such as “mental models” and “systemic structures”, SDOL can design interventions that address the root causes of challenges rather than applying quick fixes. The Iceberg Model as a serious game fosters a culture of continuous improvement and adaptability, positioning the organization for long-term success. This paper explores the application of the Iceberg Model as a physical serious game in SDOL, highlighting its significance in identifying and addressing underlying factors that impact organizational behavior and performance. © 2024, The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG.

Authors: Celik P.; Picciani J.
Author full names: Celik, Pelin (58771618900); Picciani, Jana (59500685400)
Title: Envisioning Futures Through play – Embodiment Techniques for Futures Thinking in Business Contexts
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Hochschule für Technik und Wirtschaft Berlin, Berlin, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Celik P., Hochschule für Technik und Wirtschaft Berlin, Berlin, Germany; Picciani J., Hochschule für Technik und Wirtschaft Berlin, Berlin, Germany
Abstract: In the context of rapid technological and social changes futures thinking is essential for leadership and organizations to navigate uncertainties. Traditional methods might lack engagement and creativity in business contexts. This paper explores how play and embodiment techniques, such as Social Dreaming and the Polak Game, can enhance leadership skills in futures thinking. Utilizing Future Labs in collaboration with two Berlin based global industry partners, the research project demonstrates that integrating playful and embodied approaches fosters cognitive flexibility and emotional engagement with potential futures. The findings underscore the importance of these techniques in breaking traditional thought patterns, enhancing collaborative problem-solving and cultivating new perspectives for effective leadership in complex environments. © The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2025.
Author Keywords: Embodiment; Futures Anticipation; Futures Thinking; Leadership Development; Play
Index Keywords: Business contexts; Embodiment; Future anticipation; Future thinking; Global industry; Leadership development; Leadership skills; Play; Technological and social changes; Uncertainty

Authors: Wanick V.; Black C.; Hutton C.; Barker M.; Watts A.
Author full names: Wanick, Vanissa (56523335900); Black, Cara (58771494700); Hutton, Craig (16039377300); Barker, Mary (7202354001); Watts, Adam (58823581000)
Title: Balancing Inequalities: A Board Game for Young People from Coastal Communities to Discuss Plausible Futures
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: University of Southampton, University Road, Southampton, SO17 1BJ, United Kingdom; Nucleolus Software, Preston Park House, Brighton, Brighton and Hove, Brighton, BN1 6SB, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Wanick V., University of Southampton, University Road, Southampton, SO17 1BJ, United Kingdom; Black C., University of Southampton, University Road, Southampton, SO17 1BJ, United Kingdom; Hutton C., University of Southampton, University Road, Southampton, SO17 1BJ, United Kingdom; Barker M., University of Southampton, University Road, Southampton, SO17 1BJ, United Kingdom; Watts A., Nucleolus Software, Preston Park House, Brighton, Brighton and Hove, Brighton, BN1 6SB, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper describes and summarises the design process of making a board game for young people from coastal communities in England to engage and discuss perspectives about their futures. The board game was created around imagining plausible futures and aimed at providing scenarios for players to make decisions about their futures considering social, economic and health inequalities. The paper showcases an exploratory approach of identifying game design elements based on co-design sessions with stakeholders (young people between the ages of 14–17) and experts, while using real-world scenarios and game design balancing techniques. The contributions of the paper are twofold: 1) it describes the process of making the board game via stakeholder participation, game design systems and game balancing; and 2) it provides a research-through-design method in which the design of the game reflects the intrinsic system in which young people live and suggests ways to overcome barriers established by these systems. The paper concludes with suggestions for future research such as the use of the game in participatory design sessions, mentoring classes and as an initial framework for serious games that can emerge from the discussions (e.g., teaching life skills, entrepreneurship competencies, etc.). © 2024, The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG.

Title: A Teacher-Configurable Scoring System for Serious Games
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Department of Electrical, Electronic and Telecommunication Engineering (DITEN), University of Genoa, Via Opera Pia 11a, Genoa, 16145, Italy; Wondertech Srl, Via Marcello Staglieno, 10/9, Genoa, 16129, Italy

Abstract: Serious Games (SGs) are versatile tools that entertain while addressing serious issues through digital or analog gameplay. However, ensuring continuous supervision during gameplay can be challenging. To overcome this, we propose a flexible scoring system that automates procedure evaluation, empowering learners and promoting independent skill development. By conceptualizing procedures as ordered actions with specific information, our approach enriches the learning experience, making SGs more effective educational instruments. This research advances SGs, allowing students to take control of their learning journey and improving information retention through practical experiences. With this innovative scoring mechanism, SGs hold the promise of becoming even more impactful in addressing critical educational challenges. © 2024, The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG.

Authors: Segundo Díaz R.L.; Rovelo G.; Bouzouita M.; Hoste V.; Coninx K.
Author full names: Segundo Díaz, Rosa Lilia (57375006600); Rovelo, Gustavo (55249982900); Bouzouita, Miriam (55947942900); Hoste, Véronique (23090989500); Coninx, Karin (6602251819)
Title: The Influence of Personality Traits and Game Design Elements on Player Enjoyment: An Empirical Study on GWAPs for Linguistics
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: HCI and eHealth, Hasselt University, Hasselt, Belgium; LT3 Language and Translation Technology Team, Department of Translation, Interpreting and Communication, Ghent University, Ghent, Belgium; Expertise Centre for Digital Media, Hasselt University - tUL - Flanders Make, Hasselt, Belgium; Institut für Romanistik, Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin, Berlin, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Segundo Díaz R.L., HCI and eHealth, Hasselt University, Hasselt, Belgium, LT3 Language and Translation Technology Team, Department of Translation, Interpreting and Communication, Ghent University, Ghent, Belgium; Rovelo G., Expertise Centre for Digital Media, Hasselt University - tUL - Flanders Make, Hasselt, Belgium; Bouzouita M., Institut für Romanistik, Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin, Berlin, Germany; Hoste V., LT3 Language and Translation Technology Team, Department of Translation, Interpreting and Communication, Ghent University, Ghent, Belgium; Coninx K., HCI and eHealth, Hasselt University, Hasselt, Belgium
Abstract: The present research investigates the effects of Personality Traits (PTs) and Game Design Elements (GDEs) on Player Enjoyment (PE) in the context of serious games. Three Games With A Purpose (GWAPs) were created to revise and correct automatically tagged Parts-of-Speech (PoS) of the Corpus Oral y Sonoro del Español Rural (COSER, [5], ‘Audible Corpus of Spoken Rural Spanish’), the most extensive collection of spoken dialectal Spanish data. The ultimate goal of the project is to build a morpho-syntactically annotated and parsed corpus of the European Spanish dialects through a crowd-sourced gaming environment, whereby players assign a PoS, i.e., a grammatical category (e.g., verb, noun, adjective, pronoun), to a word in an input text thereby confirming or correcting the automatically tagged PoS. This task has been implemented in three GWAPs: Agentes, Tesoros, and Anotatlón. Each game concept includes a set of GDEs (e.g., rewards, challenges, leaderboards, among others) to investigate their influence on PE. This study, which includes 54 participants, shows associations between PTs and GDEs, and some GDEs yielded a positive correlation with PE. These findings hold the potential to inspire future research and guide the design of future serious games. © 2024, The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG.

Authors: Almo A.; Rocha M.; Brennan A.; Dondio P.
Author full names: Almo, André (57211075659); Rocha, Mariana (57205182840); Brennan, Attracta (7102229392); Dondio, Pierpaolo (15020266500)
Title: A Game Design-Centric Taxonomy for Feedback Features in Digital Serious Games
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Technological University Dublin, Dublin, Ireland; National University of Ireland Galway, Galway, Ireland
Authors with affiliations: Almo A., Technological University Dublin, Dublin, Ireland; Rocha M., Technological University Dublin, Dublin, Ireland; Brennan A., National University of Ireland Galway, Galway, Ireland; Dondio P., Technological University Dublin, Dublin, Ireland
Abstract: As with other pedagogical approaches, feedback is crucial in digital game-based learning, providing information to players and impacting their learning and motivation. However, the design of feedback features varies throughout different serious games, as feedback includes many distinct characteristics. This paper proposes a comprehensive taxonomy for feedback features in serious games, building on previous classifications and emphasising game design aspects. The Taxonomy for Feedback Design in Serious Games provides nuanced descriptions of different feedback aspects and defines clearer distinctions among different feedback characteristics, creating eight new descriptive categories. This paper discusses the characteristics of feedback features, as well as the potential contributions of this new taxonomy for research and practice in the area of education and game science. © 2024, The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG.

Authors: Körner K.; Fink E.; Steiner A.-K.; Chupakhin J.; da Silva G.P.
Author full names: Körner, Kevin (57144046100); Fink, Esther (59419697000); Steiner, Ann-Kathrin (59500557500); Chupakhin, Jennifer (59500283200); da Silva, Glaucia Peres (59500420000)
Title: Graveler - Global Awareness Education Through Virtual Voyages
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: MA Specialization Digital Humanities, University of Tübingen, Keplerstr. 2, Tübingen, 72074, Germany; Center for Teaching and Learning, University of Tübingen, Sigwartstr. 20, Tübingen, 72076, Germany; Global Awareness Education, University of Tübingen, Rümelinstraße 19, 23, Tübingen, 72070, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Körner K., MA Specialization Digital Humanities, University of Tübingen, Keplerstr. 2, Tübingen, 72074, Germany; Fink E., Center for Teaching and Learning, University of Tübingen, Sigwartstr. 20, Tübingen, 72076, Germany; Steiner A.-K., Global Awareness Education, University of Tübingen, Rümelinstraße 19, 23, Tübingen, 72070, Germany; Chupakhin J., Global Awareness Education, University of Tübingen, Rümelinstraße 19, 23, Tübingen, 72070, Germany; da Silva G.P., Global Awareness Education, University of Tübingen, Rümelinstraße 19, 23, Tübingen, 72070, Germany
Abstract: This paper examines the course “What is Globalization?” offered through the Global Awareness Education program at the University of Tübingen, which seeks to transcend the typical media focus on the economic dimensions of globalization. Instead, this fully online course aims to deepen students’ understanding of the complex effects of globalization on politics, cultures, the environment, and interpersonal interactions across diverse global communities. Utilizing the 2D, web-based, role-play serious game Graveler - Globe Traveler - as both a learning and communication platform, the course employs a “virtual trip around the world” didactic concept. Presented here are the findings from four classes conducted since 2023 using this innovative educational approach. We detail the capabilities of Graveler that enhance student learning experiences and discuss the methodology and outcomes of our study, including a quantitative survey on the game’s acceptance and a qualitative analysis of students’ final assignments to assess learning outcomes. Additionally, we explore the Graveler backend, which allows users to create their own virtual journeys on topics beyond globalization, and discuss potential applications of this tool. © The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2025.

Authors: Rocha M.; Dondio P.
Author full names: Rocha, Mariana (57205182840); Dondio, Pierpaolo (15020266500)
Title: Gameplay Performance as a Predictor of Adaptive Expertise in Primary School Students
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: School of Computer Science, Technological University Dublin, Dublin, Ireland
Authors with affiliations: Rocha M., School of Computer Science, Technological University Dublin, Dublin, Ireland; Dondio P., School of Computer Science, Technological University Dublin, Dublin, Ireland
Abstract: The present study explores the potential of gameplay performance to predict gains in adaptive expertise among primary school students. More specifically, this research evaluates adaptive number knowledge (ANK), an ability to understand whole-number relations and apply this knowledge flexibly to solve new problems. Our study involved 130 primary school students playing the digital game “Seven Spells”, which focuses on arithmetic operations and numeric tables. Students’ ANK skills were assessed through a pen-and-paper timed task before and after playing the game for six weeks. Three gameplay performance metrics were collected: the highest level achieved in a multi-player mode, the highest score in single-player mode, and the leaderboard position in single-player mode. Linear regression analysis revealed that the progress against virtual opponents significantly predicted various improvements in ANK skills. Conversely, higher leaderboard positions in the single-player mode were unexpectedly correlated with some reduced ANK gains, likely due to a lack of engagement in this game mode. Student feedback indicated a preference for multiplayer mode, which may have fostered higher engagement and skill development. Our contribution suggests games can support adaptive expertise development and highlights the importance of identifying specific game design features for learning. © The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2025.
Author Keywords: Adaptive Expertise; Adaptive Number Knowledge; Maths games

Authors: Cen J.; McIntyre N.; Bokhove C.
Author full names: Cen, Jiayi (59500133700); McIntyre, Nora (57192313208); Bokhove, Christian (35931969900)
Title: Is There Cognitive Engagement When They Comment ‘Haha’: A Dynamic Analysis of Cognitive and Emotional Engagement in Game Video Comments
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Southampton Education School, University of Southampton, Southampton, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Cen J., Southampton Education School, University of Southampton, Southampton, United Kingdom; McIntyre N., Southampton Education School, University of Southampton, Southampton, United Kingdom; Bokhove C., Southampton Education School, University of Southampton, Southampton, United Kingdom
Abstract: Enhancing students’ emotional involvement and enjoyment is key to improving their concentration and educational outcomes in game-based learning (GBL), which is widely recognised as a benefit of this approach. However, concerns remain about students becoming overly immersed, which could lead them to stray from the learning goals of GBL. This study utilises Cross-recurrence quantification analysis (CRQA) to investigate the dynamic relationship between cognitive and emotional engagement in GBL settings. Fifty participants watched two Minecraft gameplay videos and engaged in cognitive tasks that involved identifying creative gameplay behaviours. The timesync comments technology was used to record students’ timed responses. After categorising these comments into cognitive or emotional engagements using Content Analysis, CRQA was used to explore these engagements. Findings revealed a high synchronicity in cognitive and emotional engagement across both videos. The second video, notable for its exaggerated narration and imaginative gameplay, triggered more frequent recurring emotional and cognitive states, indicating a pattern of more consistent engagement. The study discusses how to balance cognitive and emotional stimulation when designing serious games. © The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2025.

Authors: Re A.; Città G.; Gentile M.; Presti F.L.; Pitrella V.; Tosto C.; Perna S.
Author full names: Re, Anna (57225433965); Città, Giuseppe (56523286100); Gentile, Manuel (23466695000); Presti, Fabrizio Lo (57465475900); Pitrella, Vanessa (59349602700); Tosto, Crispino (57126275700); Perna, Salvatore (57199325110)
Title: AI-Awareness: Fostering Teachers’ Awareness of Artificial Intelligence Through a Board Game
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Institute for Educational Technology, National Research Council, via Ugo La Malfa 153, Palermo, 90146, Italy; Dipartimento Chirurgico, Medico, Odontoiatrico e di Scienze Morfologiche con Interesse Trapiantologico, Oncologico e di Medicina Rigenerativa, Università di Modena e Reggio Emilia, Modena, Italy; Dipartimento di Scienze Psicologiche, Pedagogiche, dell’Esercizio Fisico e della Formazione, Università degli Studi di Palermo, Palermo, Italy

Abstract: The integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) into educational practices offers numerous opportunities to improve teaching, learning, and assessment. However, for these tools to be used effectively, it is critical to address the role of teachers, their professional development, and the misconceptions that may hinder the adoption of AI technologies. On these premises, the idea of creating a board game designed specifically for teachers emerged. AI-awareness, in fact, was designed not only to introduce various AI tools and discuss their potential applications in the classroom but also to help teachers overcome biases and challenges they may face in their educational practice. By improving their awareness of AI tools, teachers can better understand the transformative possibilities of Artificial Intelligence in education, ultimately promoting a more informed and innovative teaching approach. © The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2025.

Authors: Botte B.; Marinensi G.; Aarts H.; Bakkes S.; Veltkamp R.
Author full names: Botte, Brunella (36760411500); Marinensi, Giada (54917117100); Aarts, Henk (7006045724); Bakkes, Sander (22333308100); Veltkamp, Remco (7003421646)
Title: Evaluating Phillips’ Game Rewards Taxonomy: Implications for the Gamification Design
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Department of Life Sciences, Health and Medical Professions, Link Campus University, Rome, Italy; Department of Human Sciences, Link Campus University, Rome, Italy; Department of Psychology, Utrecht University, Utrecht, Netherlands; Department of Information and Computer Science, Utrecht University, Utrecht, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Botte B., Department of Life Sciences, Health and Medical Professions, Link Campus University, Rome, Italy, Department of Information and Computer Science, Utrecht University, Utrecht, Netherlands; Marinensi G., Department of Human Sciences, Link Campus University, Rome, Italy; Aarts H., Department of Psychology, Utrecht University, Utrecht, Netherlands; Bakkes S., Department of Information and Computer Science, Utrecht University, Utrecht, Netherlands; Veltkamp R., Department of Information and Computer Science, Utrecht University, Utrecht, Netherlands
Abstract: This study evaluates the relevance of Phillips’ reward taxonomy in the context of contemporary video game design, with implications for modern gamification strategies. Phillips’ taxonomy categorizes game rewards into six types based on their functions within game systems. Given the rapid evolution of video games, this research investigates whether this taxonomy remains applicable to current gaming landscapes. The study consisted of two main steps: firstly, a detailed analysis of rewards in seven video games from various genres was performed and secondly, a card sorting activity with expert players was conducted. Results shown that while Phillips’ taxonomy resulted to be still applicable, the need for two additional categories, rewards of currency and rewards of self-expression, emerged, reflecting the evolving dynamics in game design and player preferences. Future research will explore the relationship between these reward categories and the fulfilment of basic psychological needs as outlined by Self-Determination Theory, to enhance the motivational impact of gamification. © The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2025.

Authors: Hojaji F.; Toth A.J.; Joyce J.M.; Campbell M.J.
Author full names: Hojaji, Fazilat (36175700700); Toth, Adam J. (56661788900); Joyce, John M. (58771664200); Campbell, Mark J. (55700473200)
Title: An AI Approach for Analyzing Driving Behaviour in Simulated Racing Using Telemetry Data
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Esports Science Research Laboratory, Lero Irish Software Research Centre, University of Limerick, Limerick, Ireland
Authors with affiliations: Hojaji F., Esports Science Research Laboratory, Lero Irish Software Research Centre, University of Limerick, Limerick, Ireland; Toth A.J., Esports Science Research Laboratory, Lero Irish Software Research Centre, University of Limerick, Limerick, Ireland; Joyce J.M., Esports Science Research Laboratory, Lero Irish Software Research Centre, University of Limerick, Limerick, Ireland; Campbell M.J., Esports Science Research Laboratory, Lero Irish Software Research Centre, University of Limerick, Limerick, Ireland
Abstract: The emerging and rapid progress of esports (competitive computer gaming) currently lacks approaches for ensuring high-quality analytics to augment performance in professional and amateur esports teams. In this paper, we demonstrate the application of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) techniques in the esports domain, particularly in simulation (sim) racing, for analyzing drivers’ behaviour based on telemetry data from race drivers. To achieve this, we used a professional racing simulator to collect a wide range of feature-rich telemetry data from 93 participants through MoTec telemetry software and the ACC sim racing gaming platform. An objective assessment of the characteristics of the driver’s behaviour was then obtained through a set of predefined lap-based metrics derived from telemetry data. Additionally, a comparison of driving styles was carried out using machine learning approaches for grouping the acquired laps based on performance (lap time). The findings from our analysis contribute to a better understanding of how elite drivers differ from low skilled drivers based on their telemetry. Furthermore, our findings provide researchers with key metrics to develop more efficient training tools and techniques to improve sim racing performance. © 2024, The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG.

Authors: Majonica D.; Fanchamps N.; Iren D.; Klemke R.
Author full names: Majonica, Daniel (57314911400); Fanchamps, Nardie (24400992500); Iren, Deniz (55762268100); Klemke, Roland (16230731700)
Title: Exploring Immersive Learning Environments in Human-Robot Interaction Use Cases
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Cologne Game Lab, Technische Hochschule Köln, Cologne, Germany; Open University, Heerlen, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Majonica D., Cologne Game Lab, Technische Hochschule Köln, Cologne, Germany, Open University, Heerlen, Netherlands; Fanchamps N., Open University, Heerlen, Netherlands; Iren D., Open University, Heerlen, Netherlands; Klemke R., Cologne Game Lab, Technische Hochschule Köln, Cologne, Germany, Open University, Heerlen, Netherlands
Abstract: This paper describes a focus group study that explores immersive learning in the field of Human-Robot Interaction (HRI). We examine four categories of HRI cases: robot-led, human-led, autonomous, and collaborative. For each case, we evaluate the potential risks and human learning outcomes. Our findings include interaction styles that can be applied in HRI as well as the directionality and (multi)modality of these interaction styles. We identified several areas of risk, including miscommunication, privacy concerns, and injuries. Lastly, we explored common human learning outcomes based on the interaction categories. Our findings fill a gap in the literature by providing an analysis of immersive learning outcomes and risks in the field of HRI. Our results contribute towards the establishment of a framework that can improve the development of immersive learning environments. © 2024, The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG.

Authors: Robison B.D.; Soule T.
Author full names: Robison, Barrie D. (7005610733); Soule, Terence (13103677800)
Title: The Design and Implementation of Biological Evolution as a Video Game Mechanic
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Institute for Interdisciplinary Data Sciences, University of Idaho, Moscow, 83844, ID, United States
Authors with affiliations: Robison B.D., Institute for Interdisciplinary Data Sciences, University of Idaho, Moscow, 83844, ID, United States; Soule T., Institute for Interdisciplinary Data Sciences, University of Idaho, Moscow, 83844, ID, United States
Abstract: Video games have the potential to help teach evolutionary biology, but most commercial games misrepresent evolutionary principles by allowing player choice to dictate evolutionary trajectories. Our game studio aims to incorporate scientifically accurate evolutionary models into gameplay mechanics. In our previous games Darwin’s Demons and Project Hastur, we designed digital genomes and implemented evolutionary models to create enemy populations that adapt to player strategies. However, accurately simulating evolution can sometimes conflict with crafting an enjoyable game. Here we examine balancing scientific realism with fun in the game design process. Using experimental data from Project Hastur, we show enemies evolve increased size and sensory abilities to counter player defenses, demonstrating the game mechanic’s adaptive capabilities. We discuss how mutation rates, population sizes, generation times and other parameters can be adjusted to balance accuracy and enjoyment, with the goal of creating engaging games that reinforce and demonstrate, rather than misrepresent, evolutionary principles. © 2024, The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG.

Authors: Dondio P.
Author full names: Dondio, Pierpaolo (15020266500)
Title: Does Playing Video Games Give a Child an Advantage in Digital Game-Based Learning?
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Technological University Dublin, School of Computer Science, Dublin, Ireland
Authors with affiliations: Dondio P., Technological University Dublin, School of Computer Science, Dublin, Ireland
Abstract: In this paper we first investigated the relationship between game habits of primary school children and their school achievements and anxiety levels. Then, we investigated if children habitually playing video games at home have an advantage when it comes to learning using educational games. In order to answer these questions, we exploited the data coming from the digital game-based learning (DGBL) intervention Happy Maths, a 6-week programme run in Irish primary schools aimed to increase maths abilities and decrease maths anxiety (MA). The dataset contained the academic achievements, the video game habits and the intervention data of 952 pupils. Our results show how playing games at home that are not age-appropriate was associated with higher MA and lower maths score, while time spent playing was associated with higher MA and lower literacy score. Regarding the efficacy of the DGBL intervention, there was no difference in the efficacy of the intervention between gamers and non-gamers. However, habitual video gamers were faster in executing their game moves, and they achieved higher scores, learning the game better. Overall, the study underlines the importance of playing age-appropriate games, and it provides evidence that, although kids playing video game might have a good advantage when it comes to educational games, the efficacy of such games is the same for gamers and non-gamers. © 2024, The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG.

Authors: Chasanidou D.; Raikou N.
Author full names: Chasanidou, Dimitra (53979395500); Raikou, Natassa (29867540100)
Title: Playful Adult Learning: LEGO® as a Playful and Pedagogical Approach
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Trondheim, 7491, Norway; Hellenic Open University, Patras, 26335, Greece; University of Thessaly, Volos, 38221, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Chasanidou D., Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Trondheim, 7491, Norway, Hellenic Open University, Patras, 26335, Greece; Raikou N., Hellenic Open University, Patras, 26335, Greece, University of Thessaly, Volos, 38221, Greece
Abstract: This paper explores the role of playfulness in adult learning and examines the case of LEGO seminars. This study interviewed trainees and educators in LEGO Education seminars and findings show that playful process in seminars could benefit adults in multiple ways. Playful elements in adult learning and psycho-pedagogical dimensions of the learning process reveal opportunities in this field. Limitations and future work are discussed at the end. © The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2025.

Authors: Fiadotau M.; Callaghan P.; Tramonti M.; Dochshanov A.
Author full names: Fiadotau, Mikhail (57195428491); Callaghan, Peadar (57219871466); Tramonti, Michela (55338114900); Dochshanov, Alden (56347101700)
Title: Wicked Problems as a Frame to Teach Environmental Literacy in a Digitally-Mediated Seminar Game
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: School of Digital Technologies, Tallinn University, Tallinn, Estonia; EU-Track, Terracina, Italy; College of Science and Technology, Nihon University, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Fiadotau M., School of Digital Technologies, Tallinn University, Tallinn, Estonia, College of Science and Technology, Nihon University, Tokyo, Japan; Callaghan P., School of Digital Technologies, Tallinn University, Tallinn, Estonia; Tramonti M., EU-Track, Terracina, Italy; Dochshanov A., EU-Track, Terracina, Italy
Abstract: The paper presents a design case study of BIG GAME, a digitally-mediated seminar game aimed at developing environmental literacy and STEM skills among middle-school students. The game employs a series of open-ended missions based on real-life environmental issues, framing the missions as wicked problems, i.e., complex problems that resist straightforward solutions due to their evolving and often contradictory requirements. This approach was chosen since real-life environmental issues fall under the domain of wicked problems, yet traditional education largely focuses on unambiguous problems with clear-cut solutions. The paper introduces the choices taken during the design process and reflects on the results of implementing the game as a competition involving 27 schools in four European countries. © The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2025.

Authors: Cloude E.B.; Kormann E.; Steiner M.; Lindstedt A.; Kiili K.; Ninaus M.
Author full names: Cloude, Elizabeth B. (57202432970); Kormann, Eva (59230064600); Steiner, Marco (59501070200); Lindstedt, Antero (55211432100); Kiili, Kristian (8304180400); Ninaus, Manuel (55797096600)
Title: The Role of Feedback Type and Task Performance on Concurrent Emotions and Interest During Game-Based Learning
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Faculty of Education and Culture, Tampere University, Tampere, 33100, Finland; Department of Psychology, University of Graz, Graz, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Cloude E.B., Faculty of Education and Culture, Tampere University, Tampere, 33100, Finland; Kormann E., Department of Psychology, University of Graz, Graz, Austria; Steiner M., Department of Psychology, University of Graz, Graz, Austria; Lindstedt A., Faculty of Education and Culture, Tampere University, Tampere, 33100, Finland; Kiili K., Faculty of Education and Culture, Tampere University, Tampere, 33100, Finland; Ninaus M., Department of Psychology, University of Graz, Graz, Austria
Abstract: Building adaptive game-based learning (GBL) interventions (e.g., immediate feedback) has been a recent effort to maximize learning effectiveness. State-of-the-art algorithms often overlook the concurrent emotions and motivation of individuals and its impact on GBL interventions. This pilot study utilized a 3 (feedback type: results, elaborative, attribution) x 2 (graph type: misleading, non-misleading) within-subjects design with MediaWatch, a GBL environment built to improve critical graph literacy. At an Austrian university, 41 students’ concurrent emotions and motivation were measured using validated surveys immediately after different types of feedback on tasks during GBL. Results showed a significant improvement in graph literacy after GBL. Different types of feedback and task performance influenced concurrent emotions and interest, but individual differences accounted for the largest variability explained in emotions and interest. The findings suggest that within-subject variability is crucial for understanding concurrent emotions and motivation to feedback types and task performance during GBL. © The Author(s) 2025.

Authors: Tataris T.; Xinogalos S.
Author full names: Tataris, Theoklitos (59501055700); Xinogalos, Stelios (13006140900)
Title: Design and Pilot Evaluation of an RPG Game for Self-assessment of Informatics and Economics Knowledge in Secondary Education
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: University of Macedonia, Egnatia 156, Thessaloniki, 54636, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Tataris T., University of Macedonia, Egnatia 156, Thessaloniki, 54636, Greece; Xinogalos S., University of Macedonia, Egnatia 156, Thessaloniki, 54636, Greece
Abstract: In this paper the educational game Mythical Empires is proposed. Mythical Empires is a role-playing game (RPG) that aims at supporting Upper Secondary Education students getting prepared for the nationwide exams for admission in Tertiary Education in the fields of Economics and Informatics, in self-assessing their knowledge on the aforementioned fields. The design of the game is presented in the context of the CMX framework, along with the results of its evaluation by 88 prospective Informatics teachers through a survey based on the MEEGA+ model and the key criteria for game design proposed by Sanchez. Positive results on the perceived didactic utility and the anticipated player experience of the target group users were recorded, while improvements were highlighted. This pilot evaluation was deemed necessary for confirming and improving the design of the game prior its evaluation by the actual target group in order to draw solid conclusions on its didactical effectiveness and entertaining dynamics. © The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2025.

Authors: Shliakhovchuk E.; Chover M.
Author full names: Shliakhovchuk, Elena (57215094577); Chover, Miguel (6602223402)
Title: Virtual Battlefields: The Rise of Video Games “Inspired” by War in Ukraine
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: The Polytechnic University of Valencia, camino de Vera s/n, Valencia, 46022, Spain; Jaume I University of Castellón, Vicent Sos Baynat, s/n, Castellón de la Plana, 12071, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Shliakhovchuk E., The Polytechnic University of Valencia, camino de Vera s/n, Valencia, 46022, Spain; Chover M., Jaume I University of Castellón, Vicent Sos Baynat, s/n, Castellón de la Plana, 12071, Spain
Abstract: The intersection of video games and real-world global issues represents a growing field of interest within the academic community. This study contributes to the discourse by examining video games that incorporate narratives related to the war in Ukraine. From storyless simple arcades to richly detailed immersive RPGs, a diverse range of fifty-six games were examined from multiple perspectives to reflect on the unique lens through which players are invited to engage with the complexities of the Russian-Ukrainian War. The study analyses content, themes, and distinctive common features, considering the broader implications of using interactive media to engage with contemporary global conflicts. The findings reveal that these games transcend mere entertainment, serving as powerful mediums for conveying complex themes and educating players about significant world events. © The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2025.
