Authors: Seater R.; Kurucar J.; Uhmeyer A.
Author full names: Seater, Robert (8696322600); Kurucar, Joel (57205743473); Uhmeyer, Andrew (57205455423)
Title: Rapid-play games for evaluating future technology
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Massachusetts Institute of Technology Lincoln Laboratory, Lexington, 02421, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Seater R., Massachusetts Institute of Technology Lincoln Laboratory, Lexington, 02421, MA, United States; Kurucar J., Massachusetts Institute of Technology Lincoln Laboratory, Lexington, 02421, MA, United States; Uhmeyer A., Massachusetts Institute of Technology Lincoln Laboratory, Lexington, 02421, MA, United States
Abstract: We introduce the HIVELET (Human Interactive Virtual Experimentation for Low-burden Evaluation of Technology) approach that uses rapid-play digital games to collect quantitative and qualitative data on the effectiveness, acceptance, and impact of future and emerging technologies. The core principle is for the player to alternate between two modes: selecting candidate capabilities with a game theoretic limiting pressure, and executing a simulated mission using those selections in a virtual environment. Alternating between the two modes allows us to collect quantitative data on performance and preferences, improve the trustworthiness of qualitative feedback, and increase the chance of discovering novel uses. We report on preliminary results from applying the HIVELET in a military context. © 2019, Springer Nature Switzerland AG.
Author Keywords: Experimental results; Gamification; Requirements analysis; Technology evaluation
Index Keywords: Game theory; Emerging technologies; Evaluation of technology; Experimental results; Gamification; Qualitative feedback; Requirements analysis; Technology evaluation; Virtual experimentations; Virtual reality

Authors: Dicheva D.; Irwin K.; Dichev C.
Author full names: Dicheva, Darina (6603619431); Irwin, Keith (8435731300); Dichev, Christo (6602913100)
Title: Oneup learning: A course gamification platform
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Computer Science Department, Winston Salem State University, Winston Salem, 27110, NC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dicheva D., Computer Science Department, Winston Salem State University, Winston Salem, 27110, NC, United States; Irwin K., Computer Science Department, Winston Salem State University, Winston Salem, 27110, NC, United States; Dichev C., Computer Science Department, Winston Salem State University, Winston Salem, 27110, NC, United States
Abstract: Gamification of education is still evolving. It lacks systematic studies assessing its effect in different contexts. Creating a gamified course is still time-consuming and design limited. As a response to these challenges, we developed OneUp Learning – a customizable platform aimed at facilitating the process of gamifying learning activities and enabling contextual studies. In this paper we present the platform architecture and its functionality, which includes support for integrating game design elements in learning activities, for creation of dynamic problems and for visualizing student performance and progress. At the end, we present a usability study of the platform and the assessment results from an end user perspective. © Springer International Publishing AG 2017.
Index Keywords: Curricula; Customizable platforms; Dynamic problem; End-user perspective; Learning Activity; Platform architecture; Student performance; Systematic study; Usability studies; Education

Authors: Valdivia S.; Blanco R.; Uribe A.; Penuela L.; Rojas D.; Kapralos B.
Author full names: Valdivia, Sergio (56239309200); Blanco, Robin (57199330169); Uribe, Alvaro (55208144400); Penuela, Lina (57189047316); Rojas, David (57216820895); Kapralos, Bill (55946696900)
Title: A spinal column exergame for occupational health purposes
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Universidad Militar Nueva Granada, Bogota, Colombia; The Wilson Centre, Toronto, ON, Canada; University of Ontario Institute of Technology, Oshawa, ON, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Valdivia S., Universidad Militar Nueva Granada, Bogota, Colombia; Blanco R., Universidad Militar Nueva Granada, Bogota, Colombia; Uribe A., University of Ontario Institute of Technology, Oshawa, ON, Canada; Penuela L., Universidad Militar Nueva Granada, Bogota, Colombia; Rojas D., The Wilson Centre, Toronto, ON, Canada; Kapralos B., University of Ontario Institute of Technology, Oshawa, ON, Canada
Abstract: Sedentary, bad posture, and repetitive movements are the leading cause of several health problems, including spinal column pain, which, can lead to work absenteeism, deterioration of the quality of life, and surgery in extreme cases. Physical activity and exercise can reduce the risk of spinal column problems, and pain. However, sustaining healthy habits, such as exercising, requires motivation and engagement. Exergames are becoming more relevant thanks in part to the use of wearable technologies that provide compelling, engaging, and motivating experiences that can help improve health care. In this work, we present the development of a spinal column occupational health exergame and a study on engagement with two motion tracking technologies, a Microsoft Kinect V2 sensor, and an inertial measurement device. Results indicate, that the inertial measurement unit performs better than Microsoft’s Kinect V2, but the game was perceived as more engaging using Microsoft’s Kinect V2. © Springer International Publishing AG 2017.

Authors: Boletsis C.; McCallum S.
Author full names: Boletsis, Costas (53979438000); McCallum, Simon (53364014100)
Title: Evaluating a gaming system for cognitive screening and sleep duration assessment of elderly players: A pilot study
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Teknologivegen 22, Gjøvik, 2815, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Boletsis C., Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Teknologivegen 22, Gjøvik, 2815, Norway; McCallum S., Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Teknologivegen 22, Gjøvik, 2815, Norway
Abstract: Using serious games for cognitive screening can provide a motivating and entertaining alternative to traditional cognitive screening methods. Cognitive decline is usually measured by tests of mental processing, however age-related changes in sleep may also reveal signs of cognitive decline among older individuals. The current work presents and evaluates a gaming system for cognitive screening and sleep duration assessment of the elderly. The gaming system consists of an original serious game for cognitive screening (Smartkuber) and a smartwatch (Basis Peak). A pilot study is conducted to identify and improve the weaknesses of the gaming system and to evaluate the gaming system as to its usability and the game experience it offers for elderly players, assesing its suitability for a large-scale study. The pilot study lasted for 6weeks and 101 gaming sessions were recorded from 5 elderly players. Elderly players were entertained by the game, while they were impressed by the smartwatch’s performance. Limitations of the study and future directions are discussed. © Springer International Publishing AG 2016.
Author Keywords: Cognitive screening; Serious games; Smartwatch

Authors: Tsarava K.; Moeller K.; Ninaus M.
Author full names: Tsarava, Katerina (56916124000); Moeller, Korbinian (23019055400); Ninaus, Manuel (55797096600)
Title: Board games for training computational thinking
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Leibniz Institut für Wissensmedien, Tübingen, Germany; Department of Psychology, University of Tübingen, Tübingen, Germany; LEAD Graduate School & Research Network, University of Tübingen, Tübingen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Tsarava K., Leibniz Institut für Wissensmedien, Tübingen, Germany; Moeller K., Leibniz Institut für Wissensmedien, Tübingen, Germany, Department of Psychology, University of Tübingen, Tübingen, Germany, LEAD Graduate School & Research Network, University of Tübingen, Tübingen, Germany; Ninaus M., Leibniz Institut für Wissensmedien, Tübingen, Germany, LEAD Graduate School & Research Network, University of Tübingen, Tübingen, Germany
Abstract: Computational thinking (CT) is a term widely used to describe algorithmic thinking and logic reasoning concepts and processes often related to computer programming. As such, CT as a cognitive ability builds on concepts and processes that derive from computer programming, but are applicable to wider real-life problems and STEM domains. CT has recently been argued to be a fundamental skill for 21                             st                              century education and an early academic success indicator that should be introduced and trained already in primary school education. Accordingly, we developed three life-size board games – Crabs & Turtles: A Series of Computational Adventures – that aim at providing an unplugged, gamified and low-threshold introduction to CT by presenting basic coding concepts and computational thinking processes to 8 to 9-year-old primary school children. For the design and development of these educational board games we followed a rapid prototyping approach. In the current study, we report results of an empirical evaluation of game experience of our educational board games with students of the target age group. In particular, we conducted quantitative analyses of player experience of primary school student participants. Results indicate overall positive game experience for all three board games. Future studies are planned to further evaluate learning outcomes in educational interventions with children.                          © 2019, Springer Nature Switzerland AG.

Authors: Jaccard D.; Hulaas J.; Dumont A.
Author full names: Jaccard, Dominique (36462577100); Hulaas, Jarle (6603251225); Dumont, Ariane (57192385018)
Title: Using comparative behavior analysis to improve the impact of serious games on students’ learning experience
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: School of Business and Engineering, University of Applied Sciences of Western Switzerland, Avenue des Sports 20, Yverdon-les-bains, 1401, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Jaccard D., School of Business and Engineering, University of Applied Sciences of Western Switzerland, Avenue des Sports 20, Yverdon-les-bains, 1401, Switzerland; Hulaas J., School of Business and Engineering, University of Applied Sciences of Western Switzerland, Avenue des Sports 20, Yverdon-les-bains, 1401, Switzerland; Dumont A., School of Business and Engineering, University of Applied Sciences of Western Switzerland, Avenue des Sports 20, Yverdon-les-bains, 1401, Switzerland
Abstract: In the last decade, the use of serious games as a teaching and learning tool has steadily increased in many disciplines. Nevertheless, serious games are still facing crucial challenges, such as their integration in the global learning process. On the other hand, with the increased adoption of online applications and courses, it is becoming possible to collect and centralize large amounts of trace data generated by players. Such data may be used to produce statistics on students’ behaviors inside pedagogical serious games, both as individuals and aggregated as groups (e.g., classrooms). In this paper we propose a classification of potential uses of statistics in serious games and give new insights into how statistical analysis of groups’ behavior may impact positively on the learning process. We also present experimental results obtained during a large-scale game deployment using the Wegas platform, our open source platform for game authoring and execution. © Springer International Publishing AG 2016.

Authors: Romero M.; David D.; Lille B.
Author full names: Romero, Margarida (36698221700); David, Dayle (57471975500); Lille, Benjamin (57195064139)
Title: CreaCube, a playful activity with modular robotics
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Laboratoire d’Innovation et Numérique pour l’Education, Université Côte d’Azur, Nice, France; CRIRES, Université Laval, Quebec City, QC, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Romero M., Laboratoire d’Innovation et Numérique pour l’Education, Université Côte d’Azur, Nice, France; David D., Laboratoire d’Innovation et Numérique pour l’Education, Université Côte d’Azur, Nice, France; Lille B., CRIRES, Université Laval, Quebec City, QC, Canada
Abstract: Programmable toys are blurring the lines between serious games and educational robotics solutions. In this study, the CreaCube activity is analysed using Cubelets modular robotics based on the Learning Mechanics and Game Mechanics (LMGM) framework. The CreaCube playful activity is used to analyse the creative problem-solving process through a playful activity made from interconnectable electronic cubes. The resolution of the CreaCube activity involves the manipulation and assembly of cubes to build a vehicle that moves independently from an initial point to a final point. After describing the CreaCube activity from the perspective of the LMGM framework, the discussion is developed in relation to creative problem solving. © 2019, Springer Nature Switzerland AG.

Authors: Schwarz D.; Söbke H.; Hofmann A.F.; Angermair G.; Schnatmann L.; Londong J.
Author full names: Schwarz, Daniel (35111879600); Söbke, Heinrich (56025039700); Hofmann, Andreas F. (57192380654); Angermair, Gerald (36975023200); Schnatmann, Lars (57204219471); Londong, Jörg (56185009700)
Title: SOA applied: Engineering software as processing unit of a serious game
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Tandler.com Ges. für Umweltinformatik mbH, Buch am Erlbach, Germany; Takomat GmbH, Cologne, Germany; Bauhaus-Institute for Infrastructure Solutions (b.is), Bauhaus-Universität Weimar, Weimar, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schwarz D., Takomat GmbH, Cologne, Germany; Söbke H., Bauhaus-Institute for Infrastructure Solutions (b.is), Bauhaus-Universität Weimar, Weimar, Germany; Hofmann A.F., Tandler.com Ges. für Umweltinformatik mbH, Buch am Erlbach, Germany; Angermair G., Tandler.com Ges. für Umweltinformatik mbH, Buch am Erlbach, Germany; Schnatmann L., Takomat GmbH, Cologne, Germany; Londong J., Bauhaus-Institute for Infrastructure Solutions (b.is), Bauhaus-Universität Weimar, Weimar, Germany
Abstract: A mechanistic model is an essential component of any simulation game. The development of such a model, including its elementary components, their relations and calculation rules, is a demanding, costly and fault-prone task. This task becomes even more complex if very realistic models are required, as it is mostly the case for serious games. Alternatively, proven simulation software can be integrated into the serious game, turning the game into an easy to use and motivating user interface, and the simulation program into a verified processing unit. In this article, we present a serious game dealing with water infrastructure planning, which interfaces to an engineering simulation software for necessary calculations. After motivating the combination of game and simulation software in this special case of water infrastructure planning, we focus on the characteristics of the software architecture and the development process. Data availability and data aggregation are identified as issues central to a successful implementation of the presented architecture. This case study thus reveals advantages and challenges of serious games employing service-oriented architectures (SOA). © Springer International Publishing AG 2016.

Authors: Spangenberger P.; Kruse L.; Kapp F.
Author full names: Spangenberger, Pia (57205741039); Kruse, Linda (57202960712); Kapp, Felix (55503241000)
Title: Serious games as innovative approach to address gender differences in career choice
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Technische Universität Berlin, Berlin, Germany; The Good Evil GmbH, Cologne, Germany; Technische Universität Dresden, Dresden, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Spangenberger P., Technische Universität Berlin, Berlin, Germany; Kruse L., The Good Evil GmbH, Cologne, Germany; Kapp F., Technische Universität Dresden, Dresden, Germany
Abstract: Serious games have been recognized as an innovative approach to introduce instructional content of subjects at school [14]. In German middle school career choice is part of the curricula to introduce different career options and, at best, providing individual advice. Unfortunately, career choices of girls are still influenced by missing confidence in their abilities, role conflicts as well as resistant discrimination and harassment in the technology field [3, 11]. Women are also still underrepresented in the game industry, however, the number of female players is constantly rising [7]. Considering this, serious games seem to be a promising approach for girls to learn about career choice. The following paper will combine career choice findings and game design to present the German serious game “Serena Supergreen and the Broken Blade” - a point-and-click adventure aiming at promoting girl’s self-concept and interest in technology associated tasks. Results of a qualitative content analysis concerning girl’s perception of the game will be presented. © 2019, Springer Nature Switzerland AG.
Author Keywords: Career choice; Girls; Serious games
Index Keywords: Education computing; Human computer interaction; Career choice; Career options; Content analysis; Female players; Gender differences; Girls; Innovative approaches; Technology fields; Serious games

Authors: Sajjad P.; Lo-A-njoe A.; Vlieghe J.; De Troyer O.
Author full names: Sajjad, Pejman (56185165600); Lo-A-njoe, Andreas (57192370801); Vlieghe, Joachim (55855157700); De Troyer, Olga (6602314082)
Title: Exploring the relation between game experience and game mechanics for bodily-kinesthetic players
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, WISE, Vrije Universiteit Brussel, Pleinlaan 2, Brussels, 1050, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Sajjad P., Department of Computer Science, WISE, Vrije Universiteit Brussel, Pleinlaan 2, Brussels, 1050, Belgium; Lo-A-njoe A., Department of Computer Science, WISE, Vrije Universiteit Brussel, Pleinlaan 2, Brussels, 1050, Belgium; Vlieghe J., Department of Computer Science, WISE, Vrije Universiteit Brussel, Pleinlaan 2, Brussels, 1050, Belgium; De Troyer O., Department of Computer Science, WISE, Vrije Universiteit Brussel, Pleinlaan 2, Brussels, 1050, Belgium
Abstract: This paper presents the results of a research on investigating whether tailoring the game mechanics and interaction modality of a game has an impact on the game experience of the player in the case of players with a high bodily-kinesthetic intelligence (with respect to the theory of Multiple Intelligences). For this purpose, we designed and developed a game called LeapBalancer, and evaluated it with a group of kinesthetic and a group of non-kinesthetic players. The results of the evaluation show that considering the intelligences of the players during game design matters and affects their game experience. In addition, we analyzed the players’ in-game behavior to explain the results. The finding are also important for learning games, since research suggest that good game experience is positively correlated with improved learning. © Springer International Publishing AG 2016.

Authors: Gentile M.; Perna S.; Città G.; Ottaviano S.; Dal Grande V.; La Guardia D.; Allegra M.
Author full names: Gentile, Manuel (23466695000); Perna, Salvatore (57199325110); Città, Giuseppe (56523286100); Ottaviano, Simona (7003467485); Dal Grande, Valentina (56410885400); La Guardia, Dario (56410946100); Allegra, Mario (56929663500)
Title: Using the educational potential mapper to design an adaptive serious game: The “uManager” case study
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: ITD - National Research Council of Italy, Via Ugo La Malfa 153, Palermo, 90146, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Gentile M., ITD - National Research Council of Italy, Via Ugo La Malfa 153, Palermo, 90146, Italy; Perna S., ITD - National Research Council of Italy, Via Ugo La Malfa 153, Palermo, 90146, Italy; Città G., ITD - National Research Council of Italy, Via Ugo La Malfa 153, Palermo, 90146, Italy; Ottaviano S., ITD - National Research Council of Italy, Via Ugo La Malfa 153, Palermo, 90146, Italy; Dal Grande V., ITD - National Research Council of Italy, Via Ugo La Malfa 153, Palermo, 90146, Italy; La Guardia D., ITD - National Research Council of Italy, Via Ugo La Malfa 153, Palermo, 90146, Italy; Allegra M., ITD - National Research Council of Italy, Via Ugo La Malfa 153, Palermo, 90146, Italy
Abstract: The frame pedagogy is a methodological framework that gives a key role to the concept of game mechanic in identifying the educational domain of a game. In this view, the activation of a subset of the game mechanics highlights a portion of the domain. Consequently, the game mechanics become a fundamental element in defining personalized and adaptive learning paths. As a case study, we discuss the implementation of a serious game called “uManager”, aimed at stimulating and supporting entrepreneurial skills in young people. In the paper, we provide a brief description of the process and the conceptual model behind the design and implementation of the game. © Springer International Publishing AG 2017.
Index Keywords: Education; Mechanics; Adaptive learning; Adaptive serious games; Conceptual model; Design and implementations; Educational potential; Entrepreneurial skills; Methodological frameworks; Young peoples; Serious games

Authors: Kuindersma E.; van der Pal J.; van den Herik J.; Plaat A.
Author full names: Kuindersma, Esther (57190065048); van der Pal, Jelke (7801492823); van den Herik, Jaap (6602619394); Plaat, Aske (6602918705)
Title: Building a game to build competencies
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Netherlands Aerospace Centre (NLR), Amsterdam, Netherlands; Leiden Institute of Advanced Computer Science, Leiden University, Leiden, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Kuindersma E., Netherlands Aerospace Centre (NLR), Amsterdam, Netherlands; van der Pal J., Netherlands Aerospace Centre (NLR), Amsterdam, Netherlands; van den Herik J., Leiden Institute of Advanced Computer Science, Leiden University, Leiden, Netherlands; Plaat A., Leiden Institute of Advanced Computer Science, Leiden University, Leiden, Netherlands
Abstract: Positive developments in aviation, such as the increased safety of air travel, advanced automation and more efficient pilot training courses, may negatively influence the pilots’ abilities to handle unknown and unexpected situations. Pilots of the older generation often have experience with manually flying multiple types of aircraft and handling all kinds of incidents. In contrast, the future generation of pilots will not be given the chance to gain the experiences in practice. Consequently, they may not have the competencies needed to handle critical situations. This paper describes how we set about designing a serious game for the acquisition of the essential competencies for critical situations. The game offers meaningful events, which match situations that pilots can face someday. The events trigger and reinforce the competencies of situational awareness, workload management, and application of procedures. © Springer International Publishing AG 2017.
Author Keywords: Aviation; Competencies; Critical situations; Meaningful events; Serious games; Zero-fidelity simulation

Authors: Abeyrathna D.; Vadla S.; Bommanapally V.; Subramaniam M.; Chundi P.; Parakh A.
Author full names: Abeyrathna, Dilanga (56925498000); Vadla, Srikanth (57205747124); Bommanapally, Vidya (57205741561); Subramaniam, Mahadevan (22434216700); Chundi, Parvathi (6507748851); Parakh, Abhishek (24366976600)
Title: Analyzing and predicting player performance in a quantum cryptography serious game
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Computer Science Department, University of Nebraska, Omaha, 68182, United States
Authors with affiliations: Abeyrathna D., Computer Science Department, University of Nebraska, Omaha, 68182, United States; Vadla S., Computer Science Department, University of Nebraska, Omaha, 68182, United States; Bommanapally V., Computer Science Department, University of Nebraska, Omaha, 68182, United States; Subramaniam M., Computer Science Department, University of Nebraska, Omaha, 68182, United States; Chundi P., Computer Science Department, University of Nebraska, Omaha, 68182, United States; Parakh A., Computer Science Department, University of Nebraska, Omaha, 68182, United States
Abstract: An adaptive 3D serious game, QuaSim for imparting to learners the fundamental concepts of quantum cryptography and their applications in designing computer security protocols is described. QuaSim emulates an often used instructional model of practice exercises followed by timed-tests (practice-timed-test) in a serious game setting by automatically designing timed-tests guided by models learned from data about the performance of players in practice exercises. QuaSim also automatically selects next practice exercises based on player performance in previous exercises. The game was played by 150 students and the results are highly encouraging. They show that the model learned by the game is able to select next practice exercises to improve player performance in the timed tests and is able to generate meaningful timed-tests. © 2019, Springer Nature Switzerland AG.

Authors: dos Santos A.D.; Strada F.; Bottino A.
Author full names: dos Santos, Alysson Diniz (56539315900); Strada, Francesco (57188761959); Bottino, Andrea (36741888200)
Title: Investigating the design and evaluation of educational games under the perspective of player experience
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Dipartimento di Automatica e Informatica, Politecnico di Torino, Torino, Italy; Instituto Universidade Virtual, Universidade Federal do Ceara, Av. Humberto Monte, s/n, bloco 901, Fortaleza, 60440-554, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: dos Santos A.D., Dipartimento di Automatica e Informatica, Politecnico di Torino, Torino, Italy, Instituto Universidade Virtual, Universidade Federal do Ceara, Av. Humberto Monte, s/n, bloco 901, Fortaleza, 60440-554, Brazil; Strada F., Dipartimento di Automatica e Informatica, Politecnico di Torino, Torino, Italy; Bottino A., Dipartimento di Automatica e Informatica, Politecnico di Torino, Torino, Italy
Abstract: Educational games are praised for their potential in providing engaging and self motivating learning experiences. However, in order to fully leverage those capabilities, game designers have to carefully balance factors that provide an enjoyable experience, without losing the focus on the instructional aspect. This work examines the design and evaluation of educational games focusing on the perspective of individual player emotions and experience. This investigation targets the following research questions: how to include (and balance) both the educational and the player experience elements into the game design? Which specific methodologies are available to evaluate player experience in educational games? After discussing possible answers to these questions, we briefly sketch directions that demand further research. © Springer International Publishing AG 2017.
Author Keywords: Educational games; Player experience; Serious game design; Serious game evaluation
Index Keywords: Education; Education computing; Design and evaluations; Educational game; Game design; Game designers; Game evaluations; Learning experiences; Player experience; Research questions; Serious games

Authors: Bajaj N.; Bellotti F.; Berta R.; De Gloria A.
Author full names: Bajaj, Nikesh (48361087400); Bellotti, Francesco (55890888700); Berta, Riccardo (6701751695); De Gloria, Alessandro (7004620974)
Title: A neuroscience based approach to game based learning design
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Elios Lab, DITEN, University of Genoa, via opera pia, 11a, Genoa, 16145, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Bajaj N., Elios Lab, DITEN, University of Genoa, via opera pia, 11a, Genoa, 16145, Italy; Bellotti F., Elios Lab, DITEN, University of Genoa, via opera pia, 11a, Genoa, 16145, Italy; Berta R., Elios Lab, DITEN, University of Genoa, via opera pia, 11a, Genoa, 16145, Italy; De Gloria A., Elios Lab, DITEN, University of Genoa, via opera pia, 11a, Genoa, 16145, Italy
Abstract: In recent years designing a game for education has become very popular. Neuroscience has developed many theories of learning, based on how brain learns. We discuss a design approach for conventional teaching methods. The proposed approach illustrates the opportunities to exploit the concept of neuroscience and combine it with game for educational purpose. The pedagogies based on neuroscience and psychology have been adapted in teaching very well and the same is expected to work well with Game Based Learning (GBL). © Springer International Publishing AG 2016.
Index Keywords: Teaching; Design approaches; Game-based Learning; Teaching methods; Theories of learning; Neurology

Authors: Antonaci A.; Klemke R.; Stracke C.M.; Specht M.
Author full names: Antonaci, Alessandra (55877136500); Klemke, Roland (16230731700); Stracke, Christian M. (35367100300); Specht, Marcus (7005896068)
Title: Towards implementing gamification in MOOCs
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Research Centre for Learning, Teaching and Technology, Welten Institute, Open University of the Netherlands, P.O. Box 2960, Heerlen, 6401 DL, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Antonaci A., Research Centre for Learning, Teaching and Technology, Welten Institute, Open University of the Netherlands, P.O. Box 2960, Heerlen, 6401 DL, Netherlands; Klemke R., Research Centre for Learning, Teaching and Technology, Welten Institute, Open University of the Netherlands, P.O. Box 2960, Heerlen, 6401 DL, Netherlands; Stracke C.M., Research Centre for Learning, Teaching and Technology, Welten Institute, Open University of the Netherlands, P.O. Box 2960, Heerlen, 6401 DL, Netherlands; Specht M., Research Centre for Learning, Teaching and Technology, Welten Institute, Open University of the Netherlands, P.O. Box 2960, Heerlen, 6401 DL, Netherlands
Abstract: Gamification is well known as a design strategy used to generate a change in users’ behaviour, such as motivation. However, while in recent years interest in it has been growing, empirical evidence on the effects that the application of game elements can generate on users’ behaviour is still lacking. We present the results of a study as a step towards designing gamification with better understanding of the possible effects that each game element could generate on end users. By involving three groups of experts: game designers, learning scientists and specialists in technology-enhanced learning (TEL), we assessed a selected number of 21 game design patterns in relation to the effects these could generate on learning performance, goal achievement and engagement of learners if implemented in a Massive Online Open Course (MOOC). Based on quantitative and qualitative data collected, 9 game elements have been selected to be further investigated. © Springer International Publishing AG 2017.
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Computer science; Computers; Design strategies; Game design; Game designers; Game elements; Gamification; Learning performance; Qualitative data; Technology enhanced learning; Curricula

We would also like to thank the participants who voluntarily took part in this study. A summary of these data can be found in [7].

Authors: Haring P.; Warmelink H.
Author full names: Haring, Priscilla (57192369170); Warmelink, Harald (37050272000)
Title: Looking for metacognition a knowledge taxonomy for psychotherapeutic games
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Independent Media Psychologist, Witte de withstraat 20HS, Amsterdam, Netherlands; HKU University of the Arts Utrecht, Lange Viestraat 2b, Utrecht, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Haring P., Independent Media Psychologist, Witte de withstraat 20HS, Amsterdam, Netherlands; Warmelink H., HKU University of the Arts Utrecht, Lange Viestraat 2b, Utrecht, Netherlands
Abstract: Most of scientific literature on computer games aimed at offering or aiding in psychotherapy has little information on how the game exactly relates to the relatively recent development of the ‘third wave’ of behavioural psychotherapy, which includes metacognition. This paper first introduces metacognition and subsequently studies five cases of psychotherapeutic games (Personal Investigator, Treasure Hunt, Ricky and the Spider, Moodbot and SuperBetter) by looking at them through the lens of Blooms’ Revised Taxonomy of Knowledge. The paper offers design recommendations for future (metacognitive) psychotherapeutic games. © Springer International Publishing AG 2016.
Index Keywords: Cognitive systems; Taxonomies; Design recommendations; Knowledge taxonomies; Metacognition; Metacognitives; Scientific literature; Through the lens; Computer games

Authors: Ninaus M.; Kiili K.; McMullen J.; Moeller K.O.
Author full names: Ninaus, Manuel (55797096600); Kiili, Kristian (8304180400); McMullen, Jake (55795530400); Moeller, K Orbinian (23019055400)
Title: A game-based approach to examining students’ conceptual knowledge of fractions
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Leibniz-Institut für Wissensmedien, Tuebingen, Germany; LEAD Graduate School, Eberhard-Karls University, Tuebingen, Germany; TUT Game Lab, Tampere University of Technology, Pori, Finland; Centre for Learning Research, University of Turku, Turku, Finland; Department of Psychology, Eberhard Karls University, Tuebingen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Ninaus M., Leibniz-Institut für Wissensmedien, Tuebingen, Germany, LEAD Graduate School, Eberhard-Karls University, Tuebingen, Germany; Kiili K., TUT Game Lab, Tampere University of Technology, Pori, Finland; McMullen J., Centre for Learning Research, University of Turku, Turku, Finland; Moeller K.O., Leibniz-Institut für Wissensmedien, Tuebingen, Germany, LEAD Graduate School, Eberhard-Karls University, Tuebingen, Germany, Department of Psychology, Eberhard Karls University, Tuebingen, Germany
Abstract: Considering the difficulties many students and even educated adults face with reasoning about fractions, the potential for serious games to augment traditional instructional approaches on this topic is strong. The present study aims at providing evidence for the validity of a serious game used for studying students’ conceptual knowledge of fractions. A total of 54 Finnish fifth graders played the math game on tablet computers using tilt-control to maneuver an avatar along a number line for a total of 30 min. Results indicated that most of the hallmark effects of fraction magnitude processing as identified in basic research on numerical cognition were successfully replicated using our serious game. This clearly suggests that game-based approaches for fraction education (even using tilt-control) are possible and may be effective tools for assessing and possibly promoting students’ conceptual knowledge of fractions. © Springer International Publishing AG 2016.
Index Keywords: Education computing; Students; Conceptual knowledge; Effective tool; Fifth graders; Finnish; Game-based approaches; Numerical cognition; Tablet computer; Tilt control; Serious games

Authors: Lackes R.; Siepermann M.; Vetter G.
Author full names: Lackes, Richard (25227196600); Siepermann, Markus (25825685400); Vetter, Georg (57199329914)
Title: The effect of uncertainty and quality perception on the usage of forecasting tools – A game based analysis
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Technische Universität Dortmund, Otto-Hahn-Str. 12, Dortmund, 44227, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Lackes R., Technische Universität Dortmund, Otto-Hahn-Str. 12, Dortmund, 44227, Germany; Siepermann M., Technische Universität Dortmund, Otto-Hahn-Str. 12, Dortmund, 44227, Germany; Vetter G., Technische Universität Dortmund, Otto-Hahn-Str. 12, Dortmund, 44227, Germany
Abstract: Forecasting tools are used in many areas of application to improve the decision making. But often, decision makers do not follow the forecast. This behavior is only desirable in situations when the forecast is faulty or does not consider all information. Otherwise, it bears suboptimal decisions. This paper investigates under which circumstances decision makers rely on or discard forecasts. In particular, the degree of uncertainty is in the focus. Results show that the more uncertain the decision situation is, the more a decision maker relies on the forecast if it contradicts his own estimation. The more the situation seems to be clear, the more he relies on his own estimation. Then, a faulty forecast can even confirm the decision maker to opt for a wrong decision. © Springer International Publishing AG 2017.
Author Keywords: Decision making; Forecast; Forecast quality; Uncertainty
Index Keywords: Forecasting; Uncertainty analysis; Decision makers; Decision situation; Degree of uncertainty; Forecasting tools; Game-based analysis; Quality perceptions; Uncertainty; Decision making

Authors: Oates E.
Author full names: Oates, Edward (57190070169)
Title: Learning and designing with serious games: Crowdsourcing for procurement
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Centre for Defence Studies, Cranfield University, Defence Academy of the United Kingdom, Shrivenham, SN6 8LA, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Oates E., Centre for Defence Studies, Cranfield University, Defence Academy of the United Kingdom, Shrivenham, SN6 8LA, United Kingdom
Abstract: This study takes a novel approach to defence procurement. Through the use of a Serious Game, developed using Open Source coding techniques and internally Crowdsourced, the design of defence equipment is developed through a wider than usual range of user perspectives. The aim is to reduce procurement cost by exposing defence equipment to a wide range of users ahead of the inservice phase, where re-work becomes more costly. Not previously reviewed the conjoining of a Serious Game, Open Source coding and Crowdsourcing has technical and cultural issues within UK defence. This is an interim report after the first year of work. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2016.
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Computer science; Computers; Cultural issue; Defence equipment; Defence procurement; Interim reports; Open sources; Procurement costs; Serious games; User perspectives; Crowdsourcing

Authors: Taneri P.O.; Akgunduz M.M.; Funda Nayir K.
Author full names: Taneri, Pervin Oya (55629912700); Akgunduz, Mehmet M. (57192369548); Funda Nayir, K. (57192382969)
Title: To recall to play in the street: A critical review of the transformation of the game concept, importance and place of game in children’s world
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Department of Educational Sciences, Çankırı Karatekin University, Uluyazı Kampüsü, Çankırı, Turkey; Department of Education Management and Policy, Ankara University, Cebeci Yerleşkesi, Ankara, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Taneri P.O., Department of Educational Sciences, Çankırı Karatekin University, Uluyazı Kampüsü, Çankırı, Turkey; Akgunduz M.M., Department of Education Management and Policy, Ankara University, Cebeci Yerleşkesi, Ankara, Turkey; Funda Nayir K., Department of Educational Sciences, Çankırı Karatekin University, Uluyazı Kampüsü, Çankırı, Turkey
Abstract: This argumentative study focused on the relationship between children’s traditional play cultures and their technology-based play. When the literature examined, it was seen that traditional games contribute children character development, as well as linguistic and communicative development. When children allowed to play outdoor and/or traditional games, they explore the nature, learn democratic behaviors, acquire creative and critical thinking skills, learn how to communicate politely with others, develop muscle strength and coordination, learn sharing and caring, and obtain problems solving skills and self-confidence. In other words, playing traditional games supports the overall development of mind and body of a children. However, nowadays, many children spend too much time indoors, by playing online games, and/or sitting in front of a screen (e.g. television, tablet pc, or smart phone). In contrast to traditional games, online games do not include social interaction. In this study, the significance of game was clarified, and both positive and negative effects of gamification was demonstrated. Consequently, the aim of this study to generate a theoretical framework that display an understanding of theories and concepts that are relevant to the place and importance of games on children’s world and disclose a critical perspective about playing games in digital world. Therefore, relevant research studies for theories and analytic models were reviewed and interpreted in order to present two sides of gamification and highlight the importance of games. © Springer International Publishing AG 2016.
Author Keywords: Contactless games; Digital games; Importance of games; Loose of contact; Play; Traditional games
Index Keywords: Education; Personal computers; Smartphones; Social networking (online); Contact less; Digital games; Importance of games; Play; Traditional games; Game theory

Authors: Mollo L.; Bellotti F.; Berta R.; De Gloria A.
Author full names: Mollo, Luca (57192371086); Bellotti, Francesco (55890888700); Berta, Riccardo (6701751695); De Gloria, Alessandro (7004620974)
Title: Building arduino-based tangible serious games for elementary mathematics and physics
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Elios Lab, DITEN, University of Genoa, Genoa, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Mollo L., Elios Lab, DITEN, University of Genoa, Genoa, Italy; Bellotti F., Elios Lab, DITEN, University of Genoa, Genoa, Italy; Berta R., Elios Lab, DITEN, University of Genoa, Genoa, Italy; De Gloria A., Elios Lab, DITEN, University of Genoa, Genoa, Italy
Abstract: This paper concerns the development of new tangible game tools for learning basic mathematic concepts. The prototypes can be easily implemented by exploiting new open source electronic hardware technologies, such as Arduino and related sensors and actuators, combing simplicity, wide diffusion and low cost. Two simple proof of concepts are presented. First, a music game, in which children collaborate to create a melody composed by different sounds controllable by changing the hand’s distance in a theremin-like approach. The second project intends addressing the concepts of distance and alignment. In both cases, they are not closed-box fully automatic games, but tools freely usable by an educator (e.g., a teacher or a parent) with children. The experience shows that several alternative configurations are easily implemented, calling for the possibility of developing a hardware/software component library for development/assembly of various types of tangible games also by non experts. © Springer International Publishing AG 2016.

Title: 5th International Conference on Games and Learning Alliance, GALA 2016

Abstract: The proceedings contain 41 papers. The special focus in this conference is on Games, Sustainability, Games for Math, Health, Soft Skills, Management, Learning and Posters. The topics include: Sustainable competence development of business students; effectiveness of using serious games; the design of an augmented reality collaborative game for sustainable development; a game-based approach to examining students’ conceptual knowledge of fractions; identifying mathematics problem solving processes in a RTS video game; database engineering game; a knowledge taxonomy for psychotherapeutic games; evaluating a gaming system for cognitive screening and sleep duration assessment of elderly players; social agents for learning in virtual environments; Parsifal a game opera; experiential learning in gameful performance art; engineering software as processing unit of a serious game; serious gaming in airport management; the RAGE advanced game technologies repository for supporting applied game development; a semantic frame approach to support serious game design; the game jam as a format for formal applied game design and development education; mobile learning game authoring tools; interest in and willingness to pay for mobile applications in museums; gamification of car driver performance; valuable tools for cultural heritage; towards computer-supported self-debriefing of a serious game against cyber bullying; gamification and scrabble; proposal of a serious game to help prevent dementia and a neuroscience based approach to game based learning design.

Authors: Kortmann R.; Luijten A.
Author full names: Kortmann, Rens (55747344000); Luijten, Arlon (57192379568)
Title: Parsifal a game opera: experiential learning in gameful performance art
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Faculty of Technology, Policy, and Management, Department of Multi-Actor Systems, Section Policy Analysis, Delft University of Technology, Jaffalaan 5, Delft, 2628 BX, Netherlands; Independent Theatre Maker, Parsifal Playingfields, and Operadagen Rotterdam, Rotterdam, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Kortmann R., Faculty of Technology, Policy, and Management, Department of Multi-Actor Systems, Section Policy Analysis, Delft University of Technology, Jaffalaan 5, Delft, 2628 BX, Netherlands; Luijten A., Independent Theatre Maker, Parsifal Playingfields, and Operadagen Rotterdam, Rotterdam, Netherlands
Abstract: Richard Wagner’s Parsifal was recently rewritten and performed as a ‘game opera’. We used observations, questionnaires, and interviews to study how the 700+ audience were facilitated to experientially learn about the show’s main themes: compassion and collaboration. This case study contributed to our understanding how performance art may improve games for learning and training purposes, many of which now are notoriously ‘boring’. We concluded that performance art’s main contribution, in particular to games discussing fundamental values such as compassion, is to captivate players and ‘lure’ them into their natural behaviour. Thus the Parsifal game opera emotionally confronted its audience with their – callous and selfish – behaviour and intensified their learning through embodied experiences. However, some players lacked time and support to (collectively) reflect on their experiences and lacked catharsis. Therefore, we recommend using gameful performance art for learning and training purposes, provided that all activities in experiential learning are sufficiently facilitated. © Springer International Publishing AG 2016.

Authors: Weijs R.; Bekebrede G.; Nikolic I.
Author full names: Weijs, Rink (57192375985); Bekebrede, Geertje (6506256847); Nikolic, Igor (16481059300)
Title: Sustainable competence development of business students: Effectiveness of using serious games
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Rotterdam Business School, Rotterdam University of Applied Sciences, Kralingse Zoom 91, Rotterdam, 3063 ND, Netherlands; Faculty of Technology, Policy and Management, Delft University of Technology, Jaffalaan 5, Delft, 2628 BX, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Weijs R., Rotterdam Business School, Rotterdam University of Applied Sciences, Kralingse Zoom 91, Rotterdam, 3063 ND, Netherlands; Bekebrede G., Faculty of Technology, Policy and Management, Delft University of Technology, Jaffalaan 5, Delft, 2628 BX, Netherlands; Nikolic I., Faculty of Technology, Policy and Management, Delft University of Technology, Jaffalaan 5, Delft, 2628 BX, Netherlands
Abstract: A transition towards a safer, healthier, more equitable and more sustainable world requires focused Sustainable Development education. While this is true for all forms of education, it is particularly vital for business education curricula, and here it is sorely lacking. The main problem is that teachers lack the methods to teach sustainability competences. Gaming is proposed as a suitable method, as it involves action, direct feedback and high motivation. In this research we used a pre-post tests research set up to measure the learning effects from three simulation games. These games were played with 160 2nd year business students. We conclude that simulation games have limited contribution to cognitive learning about SD. However, a majority of respondents see additional value of gaming within their education. © Springer International Publishing AG 2016.

Authors: Holz H.; Brandelik K.; Brandelik J.; Beuttler B.; Kirsch A.; Heller J.; Meurers D.
Author full names: Holz, Heiko (57199327644); Brandelik, Katharina (57199324866); Brandelik, Jochen (57199328873); Beuttler, Benedikt (57199329685); Kirsch, Alexandra (7103318976); Heller, Jürgen (7201486414); Meurers, Detmar (23091435000)
Title: Prosodiya – A mobile game for german dyslexic children
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: LEAD Graduate School & Research Network, Eberhard Karls Unviersität Tübingen, Tübingen, Germany; Tübinger Institut für Lerntherapie GmbH, Tübingen, Germany; Department of Psychology, Eberhard Karls Unviersität Tübingen, Tübingen, Germany; Department of Computer Science, Eberhard Karls Unviersität Tübingen, Tübingen, Germany; Department of Linguistics, Eberhard Karls Unviersität Tübingen, Tübingen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Holz H., LEAD Graduate School & Research Network, Eberhard Karls Unviersität Tübingen, Tübingen, Germany, Tübinger Institut für Lerntherapie GmbH, Tübingen, Germany; Brandelik K., Tübinger Institut für Lerntherapie GmbH, Tübingen, Germany; Brandelik J., Tübinger Institut für Lerntherapie GmbH, Tübingen, Germany; Beuttler B., Tübinger Institut für Lerntherapie GmbH, Tübingen, Germany, Department of Psychology, Eberhard Karls Unviersität Tübingen, Tübingen, Germany; Kirsch A., Department of Computer Science, Eberhard Karls Unviersität Tübingen, Tübingen, Germany; Heller J., Department of Psychology, Eberhard Karls Unviersität Tübingen, Tübingen, Germany; Meurers D., LEAD Graduate School & Research Network, Eberhard Karls Unviersität Tübingen, Tübingen, Germany, Department of Linguistics, Eberhard Karls Unviersität Tübingen, Tübingen, Germany
Abstract: Approximately 4–10% of the German population suffers from developmental dyslexia. The learning disorder afffects educational, personal, and social development of children in a negative way. Mobile serious games have the potential to support dyslexic primary-school children in addition to school support and learning therapy. We propose such a mobile serious game called “Prosodiya”, with the help of which dyslexic children can improve their reading and writing performance. Prosodiya includes innovative and evidence-based interventions that focus on improving the awareness of linguistic features related to syllable stress. We report the results of a pilot study of a preliminary version of the game. Results indicate that the children enjoyed playing the game, that their motivation was maintained, and that they wanted more levels. © Springer International Publishing AG 2017.

Authors: Kang K.; Choi E.-J.; Lee Y.-S.
Title: Proposal of a serious game to help prevent dementia
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Smartbig Co., Ltd., Busan, South Korea; The Department of Film Studies, Dongguk University, Seoul, South Korea; Institute of Image and Cultural Contents, Dongguk University, Seoul, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Kang K., Smartbig Co., Ltd., Busan, South Korea; Choi E.-J., The Department of Film Studies, Dongguk University, Seoul, South Korea; Lee Y.-S., Institute of Image and Cultural Contents, Dongguk University, Seoul, South Korea
Abstract: The incidence of geriatric diseases is increasing due to population aging. The present study aims to investigate contents that can be used to prevent, not to treat, dementia. We classified dementia symptoms into different types based on previous studies and applied related factors in our Serious game to design 17 types of mini games. In this study focusing on the prevention of dementia, the necessary contents for a game aimed to help prevent dementia were explored and a medical Serious game was proposed and designed. Consequently, this study enabled the improvement of brain function and physical activity through designing a game composed of 17 mini-games. Our study aims to contribute to preventing dementia in the future. © Springer International Publishing AG 2016.
Index Keywords: Brain; Brain functions; Physical activity; Population aging; Related factors; Serious games; Neurodegenerative diseases

Title: Training of spatial abilities with digital games: Impact on mathematics performance of primary school students
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: National Research Council, Institute for Educational Technologies, Via de Marini, 6, Genova, 16149, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Freina L., National Research Council, Institute for Educational Technologies, Via de Marini, 6, Genova, 16149, Italy; Bottino R., National Research Council, Institute for Educational Technologies, Via de Marini, 6, Genova, 16149, Italy; Ferlino L., National Research Council, Institute for Educational Technologies, Via de Marini, 6, Genova, 16149, Italy; Tavella M., National Research Council, Institute for Educational Technologies, Via de Marini, 6, Genova, 16149, Italy
Abstract: The “A me gli occhi project” has been organized to support the development and consolidation of visuospatial abilities in students of the last two years of primary school, with the hypothesis that such a training would have a positive impact on their performance in mathematics. The present paper focuses on the second phase of the project, during which twenty game based training sessions have been organized along the whole school year. Students’ mathematical abilities have been measured at the beginning of the project and at the end using a standardized math test. Results show some improvements in the experimental group compared to the control one, confirming the initial hypothesis. © Springer International Publishing AG 2017.

Authors: Söbke H.
Author full names: Söbke, Heinrich (56025039700)
Title: A case study of deep gamification in higher engineering education
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Bauhaus-Institute for Infrastructure Solutions (b.is), Bauhaus-Universität Weimar, Weimar, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Söbke H., Bauhaus-Institute for Infrastructure Solutions (b.is), Bauhaus-Universität Weimar, Weimar, Germany
Abstract: Gamification is often utilized to enhance the motivation to use digital learning tools. Usually, the effect of gamification alone is not sufficient to achieve sustainable self-directed occupation of students with digital learning tools. This statement is also confirmed by the authors’ experiences from previous uses of quiz apps to impart factual knowledge. The presented study describes the use of gamification in a university course in Urban Water Management in a twofold approach. The first approach of gamification is a gamified quiz app, which offers matches as well as ranking lists and competitions. The second approach is the gamified integration of the quiz app into the didactic context. The didactic context is characterized by the voluntary use of the quiz app and meaningful incentives, such as substitution of preliminary assessment tests. Compared to previous experiences, students showed a high level of engagement. Research instruments are the usage data of the quiz app and data collection at four points in time with the help of standardized measurement instruments (QCM, EGameFlow, and expectation-value model). The results include outstanding engagement of students indicated by an average of 2,223 questions per student answered during the semester, a high degree of confidence in mastering learning tasks among students, and a comparatively high level of knowledge improvement and social interaction reported by students. Overall, the study demonstrates the huge impact of deep gamification by integrating gamification into the didactic context and encourages further systematic research of deep gamification of didactic contexts. © 2019, Springer Nature Switzerland AG.

Authors: Mora A.; Zaharias P.; González C.; Arnedo-Moreno J.
Author full names: Mora, Alberto (57061922100); Zaharias, Panagiotis (18439002800); González, Carina (22234459200); Arnedo-Moreno, Joan (24723665000)
Title: FRAGGLE: A framework for agile gamification of learning experiences
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Estudis d’Informàtica, Multimedia i Telecomunicació, Universitat Oberta de Catalunya, Barcelona, Spain; Information and Telecommunication Systems, Open University of Cyprus, Latsia, Cyprus; Ing. de Sist. y Aut. y Arq. y Tec. de Computadores, Universidad de La Laguna, San Cristóbal de La Laguna, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Mora A., Estudis d’Informàtica, Multimedia i Telecomunicació, Universitat Oberta de Catalunya, Barcelona, Spain; Zaharias P., Information and Telecommunication Systems, Open University of Cyprus, Latsia, Cyprus; González C., Ing. de Sist. y Aut. y Arq. y Tec. de Computadores, Universidad de La Laguna, San Cristóbal de La Laguna, Spain; Arnedo-Moreno J., Estudis d’Informàtica, Multimedia i Telecomunicació, Universitat Oberta de Catalunya, Barcelona, Spain
Abstract: Student’s motivation difficulties are present in learning scenarios, even university grades. Between the techniques being applied by instructors to counteract this fact, we can find gamification techniques. Unfortunately, sometimes the result is the appearance of unwanted effects, which is a very common symptom of poor designs caused by the lack of proven methodologies for its purpose. This paper presents our first approach of a conceptual framework for designing the gamification of learning experiences. It is focused in higher education and based on the use of the Agile methodologies in order to obtain a fast Minimum Viable Product (MVP) ready for testing. Its aims are to apply different techniques all the way down to the lowest levels of abstraction through its step-by-step process. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2016.
Author Keywords: Design; Framework; Gamification; Higher education; Learning
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Computer science; Computers; Design; Agile Methodologies; Conceptual frameworks; Framework; Gamification; Higher education; Learning; Learning experiences; Levels of abstraction; Education
Funding Details: Generalitat de Catalunya, (2014-DI-006, TIN2013–45303-P); Generalitat de Catalunya; Agència de Gestió d'Ajuts Universitaris i de Recerca, AGAUR

It also has been carried out in collaboration with Grupo ICA Barcelona.

Title: Serious games: Valuable tools for cultural heritage

Abstract: Wishing to connect cultural heritage, games and social networks, the present work describes games to be used within the framework of a European H2020 project. For the purposes of supporting the museum visit, before, during and after, 5 games were designed for social networks to accomplish user profiling, to promote the museum and the application through social network dissemination, to introduce museum items and themes and to also function as visit souvenirs. The games are also presented in a generic framework for games in cultural heritage, which has been used successfully in the past. © Springer International Publishing AG 2016.
Index Keywords: Computer science; Computers; Cultural heritages; Generic frameworks; nocv1; Serious games; User profiling; Artificial intelligence
Funding Details: Horizon 2020 Framework Programme, H2020

Authors: Kim K.S.
Author full names: Kim, Kyung Sik (55710504100)
Title: Development of a serious game for the elderly (Title: ‘paldokangsan4’)
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Department of Game Development, Hoseo University, Hoseo-ro 79 Beon-gil 20, Baebang-eup, Asan-si, Chungnam, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Kim K.S., Department of Game Development, Hoseo University, Hoseo-ro 79 Beon-gil 20, Baebang-eup, Asan-si, Chungnam, South Korea
Abstract: Old people are prone to get weak in their physical bodies as well as their memorizations. We have developed a serious game for the elderly named ‘Paldokangsan4’ which is a walking game strengthening legs as well as the ability of memorization with the interface of motion capture using Kinect2, the next version of ‘Paldokangsan3’. This game machine has been installed in the show ‘PlayX4’ in Korea, last May and got responses from 40 visitors. They showed good subjective satisfactions in their responses that we could go on the project further to expand its applications to the elders. © Springer International Publishing AG 2016.
Index Keywords: Computer science; Computers; Game machines; ITS applications; Motion capture; nocv1; Old people; Serious games; Artificial intelligence

Authors: Kober S.E.; Reichert J.L.; Schweiger D.; Neuper C.; Wood G.
Author full names: Kober, Silvia Erika (36701518800); Reichert, Johanna Louise (56536144800); Schweiger, Daniela (34877702400); Neuper, Christa (7003841177); Wood, Guilherme (8646361800)
Title: Effects of a 3D virtual reality neurofeedback scenario on user experience and performance in stroke patients
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Department of Psychology, University of Graz, Universitaetsplatz 2/III, Graz, 8010, Austria; BioTechMed-Graz, Krenngasse 37/1, Graz, 8010, Austria; Laboratory of Brain-Computer Interfaces, Institute of Neural Engineering, Graz University of Technology, Stremayrgasse 16/IV, Graz, 8010, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Kober S.E., Department of Psychology, University of Graz, Universitaetsplatz 2/III, Graz, 8010, Austria, BioTechMed-Graz, Krenngasse 37/1, Graz, 8010, Austria; Reichert J.L., Department of Psychology, University of Graz, Universitaetsplatz 2/III, Graz, 8010, Austria, BioTechMed-Graz, Krenngasse 37/1, Graz, 8010, Austria; Schweiger D., Department of Psychology, University of Graz, Universitaetsplatz 2/III, Graz, 8010, Austria; Neuper C., Department of Psychology, University of Graz, Universitaetsplatz 2/III, Graz, 8010, Austria, BioTechMed-Graz, Krenngasse 37/1, Graz, 8010, Austria, Laboratory of Brain-Computer Interfaces, Institute of Neural Engineering, Graz University of Technology, Stremayrgasse 16/IV, Graz, 8010, Austria; Wood G., Department of Psychology, University of Graz, Universitaetsplatz 2/III, Graz, 8010, Austria, BioTechMed-Graz, Krenngasse 37/1, Graz, 8010, Austria
Abstract: Learning to control one’s own brain activity using neurofeedback can cause cognitive and behavioral improvements in healthy individuals and neurological patients. However, little is known about the impact of feedback design. Therefore, we investigated the effects of traditional two-dimensional and three-dimensional virtual reality based feedback modules on training performance and user experience in stroke patients. Neurofeedback performance was comparable between conditions. Interest, perceived feeling of control, and motivation were higher in patients using the virtual reality application compared to the two-dimensional feedback condition. In contrary, patients who performed the virtual reality training showed higher values in incompetence fear and lower values in mastery confidence compared to the traditional training group. These results indicate that neurofeedback can be improved with the implementation of virtual reality scenarios, especially with regard to patients’ interest and motivation. However, stroke patients might be more skeptical concerning virtual reality technique and less self-confident in using it. © Springer International Publishing AG 2016.

Authors: Kolek L.; Šisler V.; Brom C.
Title: Video games and attitude change – can we reliably measure this? The challenges of empirical study design
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Faculty of Arts, Charles University, Prague, 116 38, Czech Republic; Faculty of Mathematics and Physics, Charles University, Prague, 121 16, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Kolek L., Faculty of Arts, Charles University, Prague, 116 38, Czech Republic; Šisler V., Faculty of Arts, Charles University, Prague, 116 38, Czech Republic; Brom C., Faculty of Mathematics and Physics, Charles University, Prague, 121 16, Czech Republic
Abstract: The aim of this paper is to address methodologically the challenges that arise when measuring attitude changes toward video game content. Drawing on findings from two pilot studies (N = 18, 25) and field notes from an ongoing empirical study (N = 140), we have identified three key challenges: reliability of measurement of attitudes, standardization of game experience for each participant, and measurement of attitudes toward socially sensitive topics. In this paper, we outline our research design that tried to address these challenges. In particular, we propose modifying the game, used as a research tool, to maintain player agency while ensuring all players engage with the measured phenomena. We also recommend using the concept of attitude strength in order to measure effectively attitudes toward socially sensitive topics. Overall, this paper provides preliminary insight into research on video games and attitude change within the field of digital game-based learning. © 2019, Springer Nature Switzerland AG.

Authors: Antonaci A.; Peter D.; Klemke R.; Bruysten T.; Stracke C.M.; Specht M.
Author full names: Antonaci, Alessandra (55877136500); Peter, Daria (57199324973); Klemke, Roland (16230731700); Bruysten, Tim (57199325016); Stracke, Christian M. (35367100300); Specht, Marcus (7005896068)
Title: GMOOCs – Flow and persuasion to gamify MOOCs
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Welten Institute, Open University of the Netherlands, Heerlen, Netherlands; Faculty of Gamedesign, Mediadesign Hochschule, Düsseldorf, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Antonaci A., Welten Institute, Open University of the Netherlands, Heerlen, Netherlands; Peter D., Faculty of Gamedesign, Mediadesign Hochschule, Düsseldorf, Germany; Klemke R., Welten Institute, Open University of the Netherlands, Heerlen, Netherlands, Faculty of Gamedesign, Mediadesign Hochschule, Düsseldorf, Germany; Bruysten T., Faculty of Gamedesign, Mediadesign Hochschule, Düsseldorf, Germany; Stracke C.M., Welten Institute, Open University of the Netherlands, Heerlen, Netherlands; Specht M., Welten Institute, Open University of the Netherlands, Heerlen, Netherlands
Abstract: Gamification has gained great interest recently in several fields. However, while the literature reports that a gamification design relying on external motivation only can lead users to cognitive dissonance, most gamification approaches use points, badges and leaderboards as dominant game elements. We present our developed testable predictions with the aim of investigating additional motivational theories (flow and persuasion) to argue for a deeper integration of gamification and the learning content at hand. Relying on expert selected game elements, we consequently derive design considerations to create gMOOCs, gamified massive online open courses, designed according to the principles of flow and persuasion. Our findings are the basis of our experiment and a contribution to the development of a new theoretical design for gamification. © Springer International Publishing AG 2017.

Authors: Westera W.; Fernandez-Manjon B.; Prada R.; Star K.; Molinari A.; Heutelbeck D.; Hollins P.; Riestra R.; Stefanov K.; Kluijfhout E.

Title: The RAGE software portal: Toward a serious game technologies marketplace
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)

Abstract: This paper presents the RAGE marketplace portal (gamecomponents.eu), which is intended as a hot spot and neutral single point of access for serious game technologies. The portal aims at fostering collaborations and the exchange of technical artefacts and associated knowledge and resources between different stakeholders in the field of serious gaming (e.g. educators, developers, researchers, publishers, policy makers and end-users). After a brief introduction to the H2020 RAGE project, the flexible design of the marketplace portal and its underlying software repository are presented. A concise overview is given of the initial set of advanced game technology components created by RAGE, that are currently exposed in the portal. For empirical validation of these components, we have developed 7 serious games based on subsets of these components, which were then tested in educational practice with several hundreds of end-users. This game components portal want to be a neutral hub not dependent on any technology or provider and therefore it is open for new game technologies submissions. We envision this marketplace as a knowledge and game technologies hub to support and amplify serious game development. © 2019, Springer Nature Switzerland AG.

Authors: Clarke S.; Arnab S.; Keegan H.; Morini L.; Wood O.
Author full names: Clarke, Samantha (15044124400); Arnab, Sylvester (24528279500); Keegan, Helen (56971143600); Morini, Luca (57192084507); Wood, Oliver (57192087554)
Title: Escaped: Adapting live-action, interactive games to support higher education teaching and learning practices
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Disruptive Media Learning Lab, Coventry University, Coventry, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Clarke S., Disruptive Media Learning Lab, Coventry University, Coventry, United Kingdom; Arnab S., Disruptive Media Learning Lab, Coventry University, Coventry, United Kingdom; Keegan H., Disruptive Media Learning Lab, Coventry University, Coventry, United Kingdom; Morini L., Disruptive Media Learning Lab, Coventry University, Coventry, United Kingdom; Wood O., Disruptive Media Learning Lab, Coventry University, Coventry, United Kingdom
Abstract: Game-based learning (GBL) is often found to be technically driven and more often than not, serious games for instance, are conceptualised and designed solely for digital platforms and state of the art technologies. To encourage a greater discussion on the potential benefits and challenges of a more holistic approach to developing GBL, that promote human centred interactions and play for learning, the authors present the Game Changers initiative. The Game Changers initiative is discussed and focus is drawn to one of its programmes titled; escapED, for developing non-digital GBL approaches within the context of Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics combined with Arts (STEAM) education. EscapED, aids the design and creation of educational Escape Rooms and Interactive Gaming Experiences for staff and students in further/higher education settings. The authors present the escapED theoretical framework as a tool to aid future design and development of on-site interactive experiences, in order to provide engaging alternatives for learning and soft skills development amongst higher education staff and students. © Springer International Publishing AG 2016.

Authors: Petersen S.A.; Oliveira M.; Hestetun K.; Sørensen A.Ø.
Author full names: Petersen, Sobah Abbas (7202501424); Oliveira, Manuel (36698215600); Hestetun, Kristin (8580716400); Sørensen, Anette Østbø (57194235400)
Title: ALF - A framework for evaluating accelerated learning and cognitive skills development in industry through games
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: SINTEF Digital, Trondheim, Norway; Hydro Primary Metal Technologies, Årdal, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Petersen S.A., SINTEF Digital, Trondheim, Norway; Oliveira M., SINTEF Digital, Trondheim, Norway; Hestetun K., Hydro Primary Metal Technologies, Årdal, Norway; Sørensen A.Ø., SINTEF Digital, Trondheim, Norway
Abstract: Games have long been considered as a means to support effective learning, motivate learners and accelerate their learning. Several successful studies using game-based learning are reported in the literature. However, there appears to be a research gap on systematically evaluating accelerated learning in game environments. The main research question we address in this paper is how can we evaluate accelerated learning in game-based learning environments? The main contribution of this paper will be a framework for evaluating accelerated learning in games (ALF). We will illustrate the use of this framework by describing studies conducted in the Norwegian industrial project ALTT (Accelerate Learning Through Technology), aimed at capacity building in the aluminium industry, where we have co-designed a game for accelerating learning about the electrolysis process for extracting aluminium and heat balance in the aluminium production cells. © 2019, Springer Nature Switzerland AG.
Author Keywords: Accelerated learning; Cognitive skills; Game-based learning; Workplace learning

Authors: de Rooij S.T.; van Dijk H.W.
Author full names: de Rooij, Steven T. (8902872000); van Dijk, Hylke W. (14523705200)
Title: A game-based development method of experiential learning for aspiring professionals
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: NHL University of Applied Sciences, Leeuwarden, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: de Rooij S.T., NHL University of Applied Sciences, Leeuwarden, Netherlands; van Dijk H.W., NHL University of Applied Sciences, Leeuwarden, Netherlands
Abstract: Contemporary workers must demonstrate strong knowledge and skills of their profession. However their so-called 21st century skills such as communication, leadership, and overall teamplay become distinctive in nowadays jobs. Teaching these often tacit skills and attitudes requires an underpinned approach. In this paper we operationalise experiential learning, using a multiplayer game to create the necessary engagement. With this consequential workshop format we created a game-based workshop in which 120 aspiring professionals participated. The results of this exploratory experiment are promising. All participants left the workshop with a clear actionable view to improve team performance. The results of the personality test that is part of the workshop yield an unexpected result. A modified version of workshop may be implemented as a training recommendation instrument for forthcoming students. © Springer International Publishing AG 2017.
