Authors: Serrano-Lagunaa Á.; Torrentea J.; Maneroa B.; Del Blancoa Á.; Borro-Escribanoa B.; Martínez-Ortiza I.; Freirea M.; Fernández-Manjón B.
Author full names: Serrano-Lagunaa, Ángel (56410952200); Torrentea, Javier (56410868600); Maneroa, Borja (56410816500); Del Blancoa, Ángel (56410825100); Borro-Escribanoa, Blanca (56410953000); Martínez-Ortiza, I. (56410857300); Freirea, Manuel (56410947000); Fernández-Manjón, Baltasar (55884700700)
Title: Learning analytics and educational games:Lessons learned from practical experience
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Complutense University of Madrid, Madrid, 28040, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Serrano-Lagunaa Á., Complutense University of Madrid, Madrid, 28040, Spain; Torrentea J., Complutense University of Madrid, Madrid, 28040, Spain; Maneroa B., Complutense University of Madrid, Madrid, 28040, Spain; Del Blancoa Á., Complutense University of Madrid, Madrid, 28040, Spain; Borro-Escribanoa B., Complutense University of Madrid, Madrid, 28040, Spain; Martínez-Ortiza I., Complutense University of Madrid, Madrid, 28040, Spain; Freirea M., Complutense University of Madrid, Madrid, 28040, Spain; Fernández-Manjón B., Complutense University of Madrid, Madrid, 28040, Spain
Abstract: Learning Analytics (LA) is an emerging discipline focused on obtaining information by analyzing students’ interactions with on-line educational contents. Data is usually collected from online activities such as forums or virtualized courses hosted on Learning Management Systems (e.g. Moodle). Educational games are emerging as a popular type of e-learning content and their high interactivity makes them potential sources for relevant educational user data. However, it is still uncertain how to deploy and combine these two incipient technologies, as multiple challenges remain unresolved. This paper reports on our practical experience using LA to improve assessment of experimental research on educational game-based instruction. In the last year, we conducted four experiments evaluating game-based instruction under different conditions (using three adventure games and a puzzle game respectively) in 13 educational institutions including schools, universities and vocational training organizations. A LA system was used to track interaction around six hundred students. In these experiences, we encountered several problems in each of the steps of the process, from issues related to the design of the experiment and the game to different technical and practical problems, derived from the very diverse conditions of the facilities and policies of each institution (computer laboratories, computers hardware, software installed, irregular Internet access), which hinders the data collecting process (e.g. the system had to deal with high latency Internet connections and backup plans had to be devised for collecting data when no Internet access was available). We present the lessons learned and propose guidelines from a technical and practical perspective for the design of experimental research using both LA systems and educational games. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2014.
Index Keywords: Educational game; Practical experience

Authors: Bellotti F.; Berta R.; De Gloria A.; Ott M.; Popescu M.M.; Baalsrud-Hauge J.
Author full names: Bellotti, Francesco (55890888700); Berta, Riccardo (6701751695); De Gloria, Alessandro (7004620974); Ott, Michela (23397859100); Popescu, Maria Magdalena (55348157300); Baalsrud-Hauge, Jannicke (16233132400)
Title: Supporting collaborative serious game studies online
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: DITEN - University of Genova, Via Opera Pia 11/A, Genoa, 16145, Italy; Institute for Educational Technology - National Council of Research (CNR-ITD), Genoa, Italy; Carol I National Defense University, 68-72 Panduri St, Bucharest, Romania; BIBA, University of Bremen, Bremen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Bellotti F., DITEN - University of Genova, Via Opera Pia 11/A, Genoa, 16145, Italy; Berta R., DITEN - University of Genova, Via Opera Pia 11/A, Genoa, 16145, Italy; De Gloria A., DITEN - University of Genova, Via Opera Pia 11/A, Genoa, 16145, Italy; Ott M., Institute for Educational Technology - National Council of Research (CNR-ITD), Genoa, Italy; Popescu M.M., Carol I National Defense University, 68-72 Panduri St, Bucharest, Romania; Baalsrud-Hauge J., BIBA, University of Bremen, Bremen, Germany
Abstract: While a lot of papers have argued for the educational potential of serious games, the field is still young and methods and tools are needed in order to support effective and efficient design. The SG Studies Database is an instrument devised to allow sharing structured information about SGs. This information can be used by scholars and practitioners also to perform comparative analysis and identify components and modules that could be used in different games. The SG Studies database, which is freely available online on the site of the Serious Games Society, relies on a SG description model, that has been defined in order to allow a structured description of SGs, considering the perspectives of different stakeholders and contexts of use, and spurring the identification of SG components and their relationship with pedagogical theories and expected outcomes. The SG Studies database has already been used as a tool to support identification of reusable patterns and components in SGs, in order to identify best practices and favor module re-use. Other meta studies are possible in the future on the database by any parties. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2016.

Authors: Bahreini K.; Nadolski R.; Westera W.
Author full names: Bahreini, Kiavash (24828994300); Nadolski, Rob (6602547185); Westera, Wim (6603477787)
Title: FILTWAM and voice emotion recognition
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Centre for Learning Sciences and Technologies (CELSTEC), Open University Netherlands, Valkenburgerweg 177, Heerlen, 6419, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Bahreini K., Centre for Learning Sciences and Technologies (CELSTEC), Open University Netherlands, Valkenburgerweg 177, Heerlen, 6419, Netherlands; Nadolski R., Centre for Learning Sciences and Technologies (CELSTEC), Open University Netherlands, Valkenburgerweg 177, Heerlen, 6419, Netherlands; Westera W., Centre for Learning Sciences and Technologies (CELSTEC), Open University Netherlands, Valkenburgerweg 177, Heerlen, 6419, Netherlands
Abstract: This paper introduces the voice emotion recognition part of our framework for improving learning through webcams and microphones (FILTWAM). This framework enables multimodal emotion recognition of learners during game-based learning. The main goal of this study is to validate the use of microphone data for a real-time and adequate interpretation of vocal expressions into emotional states were the software is calibrated with end users. FILTWAM already incorporates a valid face emotion recognition module and is extended with a voice emotion recognition module. This extension aims to provide relevant and timely feedback based upon learner’s vocal intonations. The feedback is expected to enhance learner’s awareness of his or her own behavior. Six test persons received the same computer-based tasks in which they were requested to mimic specific vocal expressions. Each test person mimicked 82 emotions, which led to a dataset of 492 emotions. All sessions were recorded on video. An overall accuracy of our software based on the requested emotions and the recognized emotions is a pretty good 74.6% for the emotions happy and neutral emotions; but will be improved for the lower values of an extended set of emotions. In contrast with existing software our solution allows to continuously and unobtrusively monitor learners’ intonations and convert these intonations into emotional states. This paves the way for enhancing the quality and efficacy of game-based learning by including the learner’s emotional states, and links these to pedagogical scaffolding. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2014.
Author Keywords: Game-based learning; Human-computer interaction; Microphone; Multimodal emotion recognition; Real-time voice emotion recognition
Index Keywords: Microphones; Emotion recognition; Game-based Learning; Multimodal emotion recognition; Human computer interaction

Authors: Buendía-garcía F.; García-Martínez S.; Navarrete-Ibañez E.M.; Cervelló-Donderis M.J.
Author full names: Buendía-garcía, Félix (16229321500); García-Martínez, Sol (56410734200); Navarrete-Ibañez, Eva M (56410930800); Cervelló-Donderis, M Jesús (56410942600)
Title: An instructional approach for developing serious games
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Universitat Politécnica de Valencia, Camino de Vera s/n, Valencia, 46022, Spain; Evoluciona - Proyectos Web, S.L, Valencia, Spain; Servicio de Formación Diputación de Valencia, Valencia, 46002, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Buendía-garcía F., Universitat Politécnica de Valencia, Camino de Vera s/n, Valencia, 46022, Spain; García-Martínez S., Evoluciona - Proyectos Web, S.L, Valencia, Spain; Navarrete-Ibañez E.M., Servicio de Formación Diputación de Valencia, Valencia, 46002, Spain; Cervelló-Donderis M.J., Servicio de Formación Diputación de Valencia, Valencia, 46002, Spain
Abstract: Serious games are currently present in almost every educational context. The current work deals with the design and development of serious games based on an instructional approach to train transferable skills in public administration settings. This approach can be a valuable way of supporting instructors when they are designing games for public employees in lifelong learning processes by means of metaphors or similar mechanisms close to their working experience. Such design process is also based on modeling mechanisms in order to formally represent the game components. The proposed approach is complemented with the use of a development tool to elaborate this type of game by mixing traditional design steps with an instructional strategy to provide structured learning bites in training settings. Several game prototypes have been developed to test this approach in the context of courses for public employees. The obtained outcomes reveal the wider possibilities of serious games as educational resources, as well as the use of game achievements to evaluate the acquisition of transferable skills. © 2014 Springer International Publishing Switzerland.
Index Keywords: Serious games

Authors: Mayer I.; Van Dierendonck D.; Van Ruijven T.; Wenzler I.
Author full names: Mayer, Igor (7103174445); Van Dierendonck, Dirk (57188564773); Van Ruijven, Theodore (55338510000); Wenzler, Ivo (8608273700)
Title: Stealth assessment of teams in a digital game environment
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: TU Delft, Jaffalaan 5, Delft, 2628 BX, Netherlands; Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University, Rotterdam, Netherlands; Accenture, Amsterdam, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Mayer I., TU Delft, Jaffalaan 5, Delft, 2628 BX, Netherlands; Van Dierendonck D., Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University, Rotterdam, Netherlands; Van Ruijven T., TU Delft, Jaffalaan 5, Delft, 2628 BX, Netherlands; Wenzler I., TU Delft, Jaffalaan 5, Delft, 2628 BX, Netherlands, Accenture, Amsterdam, Netherlands
Abstract: There is not much research on team collaboration in digital entertainment games, nor is there much evidence for the efficacy of game-based team training or the validity of game-based team assessment. This is a shortcoming because of an increasing pervasiveness of serious games in organizational life, e.g. for operational training, management and leadership. Is it possible to establish marked relationships between psychometric constructs that measure ‘team composition and performance’ and ‘analytics’ that unobtrusively measure gameplay performance? If so, what are the implications for game-based team research and assessment? The authors conducted explorative, quasi-experimental (field) experiments with the multiplayer serious game TeamUp. One field experiment was conducted with 150 police officers as part of task-specific twoday team training. Research data were gathered through pre-game and postgame questionnaires on team constructs such as ‘psychological safety’ and ‘team cohesion’. A large quantity of in-game data was logged to construct indicators like ‘time needed to complete the task’, ‘speak time’ and ‘avoidable mistakes’ to measure team performance. The conclusion of the analysis is that ‘team cohesion’ and ‘psychological safety’ correlate moderately and significantly with in-game performance indicators. Teams with an unequal individual game performance speak the most, while teams with an equally low or equally high individual performance spend significantly less time speaking. The indicative findings support the need to further develop validated analytics and gamebased environments for team research and assessment. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2014.
Index Keywords: Digital games

Authors: Mannsverk S.J.; Di Loreto I.; Divitini M.
Author full names: Mannsverk, Sondre Johan (56410866600); Di Loreto, Ines (34879808000); Divitini, Monica (6701525223)
Title: Flooded: A Location-based Game for Promoting Citizens’ Preparedness to Flooding Situations
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU), Trondheim, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Mannsverk S.J., Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU), Trondheim, Norway; Di Loreto I., Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU), Trondheim, Norway; Divitini M., Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU), Trondheim, Norway
Abstract: With the global climate changes we can expect an increased occurrence of floods, even in areas not previously affected by flooding. Having the possibility to add to the traditional crisis management organization workforce also a higher number of citizens is thus very important. Despite of this, the general public seems to be ignorant of the possibility and consequences of a major flood. In this paper we present a game for promoting citizens’ preparedness to flooding situations, called Flooded. Flooded was designed using current flooding management elements, but having as main objective citizens’ sensitizations. Results of the evaluations show that the game was successful in promoting flood awareness, especially in terms of increasing the player’s knowledge of the local territory, but that a proper briefing and debriefing session is required to facilitate learning, retention and reflection. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2014.
Index Keywords: Location-based Games

Authors: Usart M.; Romero M.
Author full names: Usart, Mireia (55027240400); Romero, Margarida (36698221700)
Title: Entrepreneurship competence assessment through a game based learning
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: ESADE, Universitat Ramon Llull, Barcelona, 08034, Spain; Université Laval, Québec, G1V 0A6, QC, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Usart M., ESADE, Universitat Ramon Llull, Barcelona, 08034, Spain; Romero M., ESADE, Universitat Ramon Llull, Barcelona, 08034, Spain, Université Laval, Québec, G1V 0A6, QC, Canada
Abstract: Massive Open Online Courses (MOOC) are becoming a game changer in the field of Higher Education and lifelong learning. However, the MOOC pedagogical model is almost exclusively a reproduction of the lectureoriented approach. We introduce a Game-Based Learning approach in a MOOC that aims to encourage entrepreneurship through the use of Serious Games (SG). In this study, we analyse the entrepreneurship skills developed in a Game-Based Learning MOOC (GBL MOOC) according to five assessed activities developed during the course: presentation and participation in a general debate; an entrepreneurial aptitude test; the Metavals SG; the Hot Shot Business SG; and a final questionnaire. The results of the final questionnaire show a good perception of the utility of the GBL MOOC for entrepreneurship studies, and an acceptable overall degree of satisfaction with the use of SGs during the MOOC. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2014.
Index Keywords: Competence assessments; Game-based Learning
Funding Details: Erasmus Project; GaLA; Network of Excellence Games and Learning Alliance; Seventh Framework Programme, FP7

Authors: Mortara M.; Catalano C.E.; Fiucci G.; Derntl M.
Author full names: Mortara, Michela (6701860300); Catalano, Chiara Eva (56212265600); Fiucci, Giusy (57213110011); Derntl, Michael (6507965450)
Title: Evaluating the effectiveness of serious games for cultural awareness: The Icura user study
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: CNR IMATI-Ge, Via de Marini 6, Genoa, 16149, Italy; ORT-France, 16, villa d’Eylau, Paris, 75116, France; Advanced Community Information Systems (ACIS), RWTH Aachen University, Informatik 5, Ahornstr. 55, Aachen, 52056, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Mortara M., CNR IMATI-Ge, Via de Marini 6, Genoa, 16149, Italy; Catalano C.E., CNR IMATI-Ge, Via de Marini 6, Genoa, 16149, Italy; Fiucci G., ORT-France, 16, villa d’Eylau, Paris, 75116, France; Derntl M., Advanced Community Information Systems (ACIS), RWTH Aachen University, Informatik 5, Ahornstr. 55, Aachen, 52056, Germany
Abstract: There is an increasing awareness about the potential of serious games for education and training in many disciplines. However, research still witnesses a lack of methodologies, guidelines and best practices on how to develop effective serious games and how to integrate them in the actual learning and training processes. This process of integration heavily depends on providing and spreading evidence of the effectiveness of serious games This paper reports a user study to evaluate the effectiveness of Icura, a serious game about Japanese culture and etiquette. The evaluation methodology extends the set of instruments used in previous studies by evaluating the effects of the game on raising awareness, by avoiding the selective attention bias and by assessing the medium-term retention. With this research we aim to provide a handy toolkit for evaluating the effectiveness a serious games for cultural awareness and heritage.  © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2014.
Index Keywords: Cultural awareness; Serious games; User study
Funding Details: European Commission in the Seventh Framework Programme Network of Excellence, (258169, FP7-ICT-2009.4.2)

Author full names: Gongsook, Pongpanote (55535168900); Peijnenborgh, Janneke (56410835000); van der Spek, Erik (24833884000); Hu, Jun (56442891500); Bellotti, Francesco (55890888700); Berta, Riccardo (6701751695); de Gloria, Alessandro (7004620974); Curatelli, Francesco (57154509300); Martinengo, Chiara (12779019400); Rauterberg, Matthias (6701479494); Hendriksen, Jos (6701625932)
Title: Designing a serious game as a diagnostic tool
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Department of Industrial Design, Eindhoven University of Technology, Eindhoven, MB, 5600, Netherlands; Kempenhaeghe, Center for Neurological Learning Disabilities, Heeze, VE, 5591, Netherlands; ELIOS Lab - DITEN, University of Genova, Via Opera Pia 11/a, Genova, 16145, Italy; DIMA - University of Genova, Via Dodecaneso, 35, Genova, 16145, Italy

Abstract: Serious games offer the potential to not only entertain and educate, but can also operate as a diagnostic tool. While designing a game with the goal of a diagnostic tool, we faced many challenges. In this paper, we share our experiences in dealing with these challenges in the iterations of designing, implementing, and evaluating such a tool. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2015.

Authors: Kim K.S.; Lee Y.J.; Oh D.N.
Author full names: Kim, Kyung Sik (55710504100); Lee, Yoon Jung (55781455700); Oh, Doo Nam (56735362000)
Title: Development and testing of a serious game for the elderly (title: ‘Paldokangsan3’)
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Department of Game Development, Hoseo University, Hoseo-ro 79 Beon-gil 20, Baebang-eup, Asan-si, Chungnam, South Korea; Department of Social Welfare for the Elderly, Hoseo University, Hoseodae-kil 12, Dongnam-ku, Cheonan-si, Chungnam, South Korea; Department of Nursing, Hoseo University, Hoseo-ro 79 Beon-gil 20, Baebang-eup, Asan-si, Chungnam, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Kim K.S., Department of Game Development, Hoseo University, Hoseo-ro 79 Beon-gil 20, Baebang-eup, Asan-si, Chungnam, South Korea; Lee Y.J., Department of Social Welfare for the Elderly, Hoseo University, Hoseodae-kil 12, Dongnam-ku, Cheonan-si, Chungnam, South Korea; Oh D.N., Department of Nursing, Hoseo University, Hoseo-ro 79 Beon-gil 20, Baebang-eup, Asan-si, Chungnam, South Korea
Abstract: Old people are prone to get weak in their physical bodies as well as their memorizations. We have developed a serious game for the elderly named ‘Paldokangsan3’ which is a walking game strengthening legs as well as the ability of memorization with the interface of motion capture using Kinect. Also we have evaluated the usability test of ‘Paldokangsan3’. This game machine has been installed in a senior house for one month that the elderly could play the game as they like in the house. Most participants played 2–3 times a day for a month even though most of them are suffering mild cognition impairment. They showed good subjective satisfactions in their interviews that we could go on the project further to expand its applications. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2016.

Title: The absolute and social comparative analysis of driver performance on a simulated road network
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: DITEN, University of Genoa, Via Opera Pia 11A, Genoa, 16145, Italy; Automotive Services and Communication Technologies, Fraunhofer Institute for Open Communication Systems FOKUS, Kaiserin-Augusta-Allee 31, Berlin, 10589, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Dange G.R., DITEN, University of Genoa, Via Opera Pia 11A, Genoa, 16145, Italy; Paranthaman P.K., DITEN, University of Genoa, Via Opera Pia 11A, Genoa, 16145, Italy; Samaritani M., DITEN, University of Genoa, Via Opera Pia 11A, Genoa, 16145, Italy; Smiai O., DITEN, University of Genoa, Via Opera Pia 11A, Genoa, 16145, Italy; Bellotti F., DITEN, University of Genoa, Via Opera Pia 11A, Genoa, 16145, Italy; Berta R., DITEN, University of Genoa, Via Opera Pia 11A, Genoa, 16145, Italy; De Gloria A., DITEN, University of Genoa, Via Opera Pia 11A, Genoa, 16145, Italy; Marchesoni M., DITEN, University of Genoa, Via Opera Pia 11A, Genoa, 16145, Italy; Massucc S., DITEN, University of Genoa, Via Opera Pia 11A, Genoa, 16145, Italy; Pontow J., Automotive Services and Communication Technologies, Fraunhofer Institute for Open Communication Systems FOKUS, Kaiserin-Augusta-Allee 31, Berlin, 10589, Germany
Abstract: The process of modeling a qualitative evaluation schema to gauge the driver performance is a prominent aspect in enhancing the driving standards. We have implemented a comparative analysis module to estimate the driver performance based on absolute and social comparisons. In this approach we simulated a road network of 40 vehicle users and analyzed the performance of the users by our interlinked system architecture dedicated for simulation, data sharing and representation of the entire information on Map-based user interface. Another key aspect that was performed in this approach was the usage of Map-Matching module to discard the inaccuracies in Geo-references while representing the coordinates on Google Maps. We believe, this evaluation approach will broaden the overview of performance analysis and provide more insight to the user on all grounds in improvising the driving standards. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2016.
Index Keywords: Roads and streets; Comparative analysis; Data Sharing; Driver performance; Evaluation approach; Performance analysis; Qualitative evaluations; System architectures; Vehicle users; User interfaces

Authors: Torrente J.; Serrano-Laguna Á.; Del Blanco Aguado Á.; Moreno-Ger P.; Fernández-Manjón B.
Author full names: Torrente, Javier (24482065900); Serrano-Laguna, Ángel (56685528300); Del Blanco Aguado, Ángel (55189885600); Moreno-Ger, Pablo (8951372100); Fernández-Manjón, Baltasar (55884700700)
Title: Development of a game engine for accessible web-based games
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: UCM, Madrid, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Torrente J., UCM, Madrid, Spain; Serrano-Laguna Á., UCM, Madrid, Spain; Del Blanco Aguado Á., UCM, Madrid, Spain; Moreno-Ger P., UCM, Madrid, Spain; Fernández-Manjón B., UCM, Madrid, Spain
Abstract: The Web is rapidly shifting towards more dynamic and interactive content. One clear example is the increasing use of web-based digital games. However, the more interactive a piece of content is, the more difficult it is to make it universally accessible. Besides, users are increasingly demanding ubiquitous access to the content and applications they use (including games), resulting in a need for ensuring that Web content is also multiplatform. These trends are adding an extra technology challenge for ensuring content accessibility. In this paper we describe our technical approach to create an accessible multiplatform game engine for the new version of the eAdventure educational game authoring platform (eAdventure 2.0). This approach integrates accessibility as a core design principle instead of adding accessibility features a posteriori. We expect this to facilitate the creation of web-based digital games that are accessible regardless of the context (device, assistive tools available, situation, etc.) in which they are being used. In this work we describe the general architecture, as well as some specific examples of accessibility adaptation plugins already available. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2014.
Index Keywords: Game Engine

Authors: Bahreini K.; Nadolski R.; Westera W.
Author full names: Bahreini, Kiavash (24828994300); Nadolski, Rob (6602547185); Westera, Wim (6603477787)
Title: Improved multimodal emotion recognition for better game-based learning
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Welten Institute, Research Centre for Learning, Teaching and Technology, Open University of the Netherlands, Valkenburgerweg 177, Heerlen, 6419, AT, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Bahreini K., Welten Institute, Research Centre for Learning, Teaching and Technology, Open University of the Netherlands, Valkenburgerweg 177, Heerlen, 6419, AT, Netherlands; Nadolski R., Welten Institute, Research Centre for Learning, Teaching and Technology, Open University of the Netherlands, Valkenburgerweg 177, Heerlen, 6419, AT, Netherlands; Westera W., Welten Institute, Research Centre for Learning, Teaching and Technology, Open University of the Netherlands, Valkenburgerweg 177, Heerlen, 6419, AT, Netherlands
Abstract: This paper introduces the integration of the face emotion recognition part and the voice emotion recognition part of our FILTWAM framework that uses webcams and microphones. This framework enables real-time multimodal emotion recognition of learners during game-based learning for triggering feedback towards improved learning. The main goal of this study is to validate the integration of webcam and microphone data for a real-time and adequate interpretation of facial and vocal expressions into emotional states where the software modules are calibrated with end users. This integration aims to improve timely and relevant feedback, which is expected to increase learners’ awareness of their own behavior. Twelve test persons received the same computer-based tasks in which they were requested to mimic specific facial and vocal expressions. Each test person mimicked 80 emotions, which led to a dataset of 960 emotions. All sessions were recorded on video. An overall accuracy of Kappa value based on the requested emotions, expert opinions, and the recognized emotions is 0.61, of the face emotion recognition software is 0.76, and of the voice emotion recognition software is 0.58. A multimodal fusion between the software modules can increase the accuracy to 78 %. In contrast with existing software our software modules allow real-time, continuously and unobtrusively monitoring of learners’ face expressions and voice intonations and convert these into emotional states. This inclusion of learner’s emotional states paves the way for more effective, efficient and enjoyable game-based learning. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2015.

Authors: Bond D.; Loidl H.-W.; Louchart S.
Author full names: Bond, David (57196697623); Loidl, Hans-Wolfgang (8898020300); Louchart, Sandy (14010506300)
Title: Design and implementation of the jomini engine: Towards a historical massively multiplayer online role-playing game
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Heriot-Watt University, Riccarton Campus, Edinburgh, EH14 4AS, United Kingdom; Digital Design Studio, The Glasgow School of Art, The Hub, Pacific Quay, G51 1EA, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Bond D., Heriot-Watt University, Riccarton Campus, Edinburgh, EH14 4AS, United Kingdom; Loidl H.-W., Heriot-Watt University, Riccarton Campus, Edinburgh, EH14 4AS, United Kingdom; Louchart S., Digital Design Studio, The Glasgow School of Art, The Hub, Pacific Quay, G51 1EA, United Kingdom
Abstract: This technical paper describes the design and implementation of a game engine for historical massive multiplayer online role-playing games (MMORPGs). We explore the game and system design space with a focus on historical accuracy and provide a detailed discussion of key design goals for the support of a large-scale, distributed and scalable MMORPG. The JominiEngine is a modular and extensible system architecture built on C# and integrates Riak, a non-SQL database, at the core of the persistent data store in order to facilitate scalability. “Overlord”, the first instance of the engine is set in the medieval time period and uses rigorous UML design methodology for both game and system design. In order to enhance the immersive gaming experience, a separate Unitybased client can be used to interact with the game engine. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2016.

Authors: Sotirakou C.; Mourlas C.
Author full names: Sotirakou, Catherine (57188707653); Mourlas, Constantinos (35088636400)
Title: A gamified news application for mobile devices: An approach that turns digital news readers into players of a social network
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Faculty of Communication and Media Studies, University of Athens, Athens, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Sotirakou C., Faculty of Communication and Media Studies, University of Athens, Athens, Greece; Mourlas C., Faculty of Communication and Media Studies, University of Athens, Athens, Greece
Abstract: Gamification is a well known approach nowadays for achieving the ultimate goal of motivating loyalty with a brand and engaging users with given tasks in a variety of fields. However, attempts made to use gamification techniques in news industry have given poor results, pointing to the conclusion that journalism may not an open field for gamification to thrive. At the same time changes in news consumption across the globe show a rapid rise of news audiences accessing stories through their mobile devices, while social media play a huge role in distribution of online news. This paper examines the combination of these three trends, gamification, smartphones and social media in a promising and possibly successful way. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2016.
Author Keywords: Digital media; Game design; Gamification; Journalism; Mobile news reader; Social interaction
Index Keywords: Digital devices; Digital storage; Mobile devices; Game design; Gamification; Journalism; Mobile news reader; Social interactions; Social networking (online)

Title: 4th International Conference on Games and Learning Alliance, GALA 2015
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Abstract: The proceedings contain 60 papers. The special focus in this conference is on Games and Learning Alliance. The topics include: A model-driven framework for educational game design; a serious game to analyze complex decision-making in air traffic management; the double-effect approach to serious games in higher education; students designing and developing serious games for other students; instructions and feedback in connection with the duration and the level of difficulty of a serious game; learning and designing with serious games; development of mobile serious game for self-assessment as base for a game-editor for teachers; a prosocial co-op game for building up trustworthiness and teamwork; digital game design as a complex learning activity for developing the 4cs skills; social practices for social driven conversations in serious games; a comparison of methodological frameworks for digital learning game design; immersive technologies and natural interaction to improve serious games engagement; game and learning mechanics under the perspective of self-determination theory for supporting motivation in digital game based learning; mobile game based learning based on adaptive curricula and location change; a design framework for experiential history games; teaching statistics and risk management with card games; simulation-based serious games for science education in elementary and middle schools; English vocabulary learning system based on repetitive learning and rate-matching rule; an information theoretic approach for measuring data discovery and utilization during analytical and decision-making processes and comparing game input modalities.
Editors: Veltkamp R.; de Gloria A.
Conference name: 4th International Conference on Games and Learning Alliance, GALA 2015

Authors: Gongsook P.; Peijnenborgh J.; Sallustro C.; Van Der Spek E.; Hu J.; Bellotti F.; Rauterberg M.; Hendriksen J.

Title: A diagnostic tool on time perception of children with ADHD
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Department of Industrial Design, Eindhoven University of Technology, MB Eindhoven, 5600, Netherlands; Kempenhaeghe, Center for Neurological Learning Disabilities, VE Heeze, 5591, Netherlands; ELIOS Lab - DITEN, University of Genova, Via Opera Pia 11/a, Genoa, 16145, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Gongsook P., Department of Industrial Design, Eindhoven University of Technology, MB Eindhoven, 5600, Netherlands; Peijnenborgh J., Kempenhaeghe, Center for Neurological Learning Disabilities, VE Heeze, 5591, Netherlands; Sallustro C., Department of Industrial Design, Eindhoven University of Technology, MB Eindhoven, 5600, Netherlands; Van Der Spek E., Department of Industrial Design, Eindhoven University of Technology, MB Eindhoven, 5600, Netherlands; Hu J., Department of Industrial Design, Eindhoven University of Technology, MB Eindhoven, 5600, Netherlands; Bellotti F., ELIOS Lab - DITEN, University of Genova, Via Opera Pia 11/a, Genoa, 16145, Italy; Rauterberg M., Department of Industrial Design, Eindhoven University of Technology, MB Eindhoven, 5600, Netherlands; Hendriksen J., Kempenhaeghe, Center for Neurological Learning Disabilities, VE Heeze, 5591, Netherlands
Abstract: ADHD is among the most common childhood developmental disorder which may affect the school achievements. Children with ADHD may show symptoms of time perception problems. Although ADHD is a clinical diagnosis with several approaches, no diagnostic tool has been designed to detect the symptoms of time perception problems in ADHD children. A computer game can be a powerful tool to be used as part of the psychological assessment and yield better accuracy in ADHD diagnosis. In this paper, we present our concept of a diagnostic tool on time perception for children with ADHD-symptoms. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2014.

Authors: Apostolakis K.C.; Kaza K.; Psaltis A.; Stefanidis K.; Thermos S.; Dimitropoulos K.; Dimaraki E.; Daras P.
Author full names: Apostolakis, Konstantinos C. (55339270200); Kaza, Kyriaki (57190066799); Psaltis, Athanasios (57190073285); Stefanidis, Kiriakos (57190065039); Thermos, Spyridon (57190068868); Dimitropoulos, Kosmas (22950021000); Dimaraki, Evaggelia (53881201300); Daras, Petros (6602644373)
Title: Path of trust: A prosocial co-op game for building up trustworthiness and teamwork
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Information Technologies Institute, Centre for Research and Technology Hellas, Thessaloniki, Greece; Ellinogermaniki Agogi, Pallini, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Apostolakis K.C., Information Technologies Institute, Centre for Research and Technology Hellas, Thessaloniki, Greece; Kaza K., Information Technologies Institute, Centre for Research and Technology Hellas, Thessaloniki, Greece; Psaltis A., Information Technologies Institute, Centre for Research and Technology Hellas, Thessaloniki, Greece; Stefanidis K., Information Technologies Institute, Centre for Research and Technology Hellas, Thessaloniki, Greece; Thermos S., Information Technologies Institute, Centre for Research and Technology Hellas, Thessaloniki, Greece; Dimitropoulos K., Information Technologies Institute, Centre for Research and Technology Hellas, Thessaloniki, Greece; Dimaraki E., Ellinogermaniki Agogi, Pallini, Greece; Daras P., Information Technologies Institute, Centre for Research and Technology Hellas, Thessaloniki, Greece
Abstract: In this paper, a two-player digital game is presented, that attempts to balance the exciting game content and story-driven elements mostly associated with games in the entertainment industry with a serious game agenda. The latter focuses on teaching children aged 7–10 the importance of understanding the benefits of cooperation as well as expressing trustworthiness. Gamification of Prosocial Theory has led to several game mechanics being redefined, in order to turn traditional games’ elements of competition into cooperation evaluation mechanisms. Using these mechanisms, children are called upon to adapt their gameplay behavior towards expressing prosociality and understanding each other’s needs. Our experiments solidify this concept, by showcasing promising indications on the game’s potential to help children understand when it is a good idea to adopt a prosocial behavior. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2016.
Author Keywords: Game design; Multiplayer games; Prosocial behaviour; Serious games
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Computer science; Computers; Digital games; Entertainment industry; Game contents; Game design; Gamification; Multiplayer games; Prosocial behaviour; Serious games; Education

Authors: Opromolla A.; Ingrosso A.; Volpi V.; Medaglia C.M.; Palatucci M.; Pazzola M.
Author full names: Opromolla, Antonio (55204791400); Ingrosso, Andrea (55344496400); Volpi, Valentina (56826327000); Medaglia, Carlo Maria (8921632800); Palatucci, Mauro (56938647600); Pazzola, Mariarosaria (56245614200)
Title: Gamification in a smart city context. An analysis and a proposal for its application in co-design processes
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: ISIA Roma Design, Piazza della Maddalena 53, Rome, 00196, Italy; CORIS, Sapienza Università di Roma, Via Salaria 113, Rome, 00198, Italy; DIAG, Sapienza Università di Roma, Piazzale Aldo Moro 5, Rome, 00185, Italy; Link Campus University, Via Nomentana 335, Rome, 00162, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Opromolla A., ISIA Roma Design, Piazza della Maddalena 53, Rome, 00196, Italy, Link Campus University, Via Nomentana 335, Rome, 00162, Italy; Ingrosso A., CORIS, Sapienza Università di Roma, Via Salaria 113, Rome, 00198, Italy; Volpi V., ISIA Roma Design, Piazza della Maddalena 53, Rome, 00196, Italy, Link Campus University, Via Nomentana 335, Rome, 00162, Italy; Medaglia C.M., DIAG, Sapienza Università di Roma, Piazzale Aldo Moro 5, Rome, 00185, Italy; Palatucci M., ISIA Roma Design, Piazza della Maddalena 53, Rome, 00196, Italy; Pazzola M., ISIA Roma Design, Piazza della Maddalena 53, Rome, 00196, Italy
Abstract: In the academic debate on smart city definition, the “human” part of the city is gaining a prominent position as a decisive factor in good city policies. So, Public Administrations (PAs) are looking for the citizen involvement in the decision-making processes, in order to create products and services really meeting the city needs. In this context, gamification principles are more and more employed as facilitator of the citizen engagement process. In this paper, we intend to show the main findings of our analysis on the literary review about application of gamification principles in the smart city context, providing some considerations about their possible application in public policies co-design. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2015.
Index Keywords: Decision making; Citizen engagements; Citizen involvement; Co-designs; Decision making process; Gamification; ITS applications; Products and services; Smart cities; Public administration

Authors: Siepermann M.
Author full names: Siepermann, Markus (25825685400)
Title: Teaching statistics and risk management with card games
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Technische Universität Dortmund, Otto-Hahn-Str. 12, Dortmund, 44227, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Siepermann M., Technische Universität Dortmund, Otto-Hahn-Str. 12, Dortmund, 44227, Germany
Abstract: Very often, students lack of understanding and motivation for formal concepts like programming, modelling, mathematics, or statistics although these are key skills and very important for disciplines like risk management. In this paper, we present a learning system based on the simple card game High or Low that helps to teach fundamental principles of statistics and risk management. In addition, we provide a computer prognosis to the players. Results show that if students are forced to calculate the likelihood and make the decision which option to choose on their own, the outcome is acceptable. But if a computer generated prognosis is given, a high percentage of students rely on the prognosis even if it is obviously not correct. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2016.
Author Keywords: Card games; Game based learning; Risk management; Statistics
Index Keywords: Risk assessment; Statistics; Students; Card games; Computer generated; Formal concepts; Fundamental principles; Game-based Learning; Teaching statistics; Risk management

Author full names: Carvalho, Maira B. (55841076700); Bellotti, Francesco (55890888700); Berta, Riccardo (6701751695); Curatelli, Francesco (57154509300); De Gloria, Alessandro (7004620974); Gazzarata, Giorgia (56444342500); Hu, Jun (56442891500); Kickmeier-Rust, Michael (23397084000); Martinengo, Chiara (12779019400)
Title: The journey: A service-based adaptive serious game on probability
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: DITEN, University of Genoa, Via Opera Pia 11A, Genoa, 16145, Italy; Department of Industrial Design, Eindhoven University of Technology, P.O. Box 513, Eindhoven, 5600, MB, Netherlands; Knowledge Technologies Institute, Graz University of Technology, Inffeldgasse 13, Graz, 8010, Austria; DIMA, University of Genoa, Via Dodecaneso 35, Genoa, 16146, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Carvalho M.B., DITEN, University of Genoa, Via Opera Pia 11A, Genoa, 16145, Italy; Bellotti F., DITEN, University of Genoa, Via Opera Pia 11A, Genoa, 16145, Italy; Berta R., DITEN, University of Genoa, Via Opera Pia 11A, Genoa, 16145, Italy; Curatelli F., DITEN, University of Genoa, Via Opera Pia 11A, Genoa, 16145, Italy; De Gloria A., DITEN, University of Genoa, Via Opera Pia 11A, Genoa, 16145, Italy; Gazzarata G., DITEN, University of Genoa, Via Opera Pia 11A, Genoa, 16145, Italy; Hu J., Department of Industrial Design, Eindhoven University of Technology, P.O. Box 513, Eindhoven, 5600, MB, Netherlands; Kickmeier-Rust M., Knowledge Technologies Institute, Graz University of Technology, Inffeldgasse 13, Graz, 8010, Austria; Martinengo C., DIMA, University of Genoa, Via Dodecaneso 35, Genoa, 16146, Italy
Abstract: Serious Games (SGs) have a lot of potential in education, possibly making learning more engaging and satisfying. Adaptive Games strive to keep the challenges presented by the game balanced with the player’s abilities, as to keep the player in the “flow” state. We have used a Service-Oriented Architecture (SOA) approach to develop a simple adaptive SG for teaching basic elements of probability to high school and entry-level university students, called The Journey. The game performs continuously the updating of a user model with the competences of the student and presents the new challenges according to the student’s current level. This paper presents details of the educational aspects of the game, as well as of its implementation. It also presents a preliminary validation study and discusses future work. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2015.

Authors: Frank E.; Lackes R.; Siepermann M.
Author full names: Frank, Erik (36767440000); Lackes, Richard (25227196600); Siepermann, Markus (25825685400)
Title: Mobile game based learning based on adaptive curricula and location change
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Technische Universität Dortmund, Otto-Hahn-Str. 12, Dortmund, 44227, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Frank E., Technische Universität Dortmund, Otto-Hahn-Str. 12, Dortmund, 44227, Germany; Lackes R., Technische Universität Dortmund, Otto-Hahn-Str. 12, Dortmund, 44227, Germany; Siepermann M., Technische Universität Dortmund, Otto-Hahn-Str. 12, Dortmund, 44227, Germany
Abstract: With the diffusion of mobile technologies, the classic learning process of class room learning as well as e-learning has changed. Mobile devices enable individuals to learn anywhere and anytime, even if only little time is available. Usually, m-learning is often seen as e-learning on mobile devices. This disregards the real potential of m-learning. Instead, the characteristics of mobility should be taken into account when designing m-learning, namely different places of learning and the process of location change. In this paper, we therefore introduce the concept of location-sequence-based learning (LSBL) that explicitly considers these characteristics. Then, we combine LSBL with the concept of game based learning (GBL) in order to even enhance the motivational aspect of both concepts. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2016.

Authors: Sillaots M.
Author full names: Sillaots, Martin (34977387500)
Title: Using avatars for course management and immersion
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Tallinn University, Tallinn, Estonia
Authors with affiliations: Sillaots M., Tallinn University, Tallinn, Estonia
Abstract: Gamification is the use of game elements in non-game environment. One element among others is avatar. The use of avatar in the context of learning can make students to feel themselves more safe and relaxed. It can lead to the more active participation and to immersion. To find out what is the effect of using avatars in education, several courses were designed like games, and feedback information was collected It was found that implementation of avatars was useful for creating anonymous scoreboards, however it did not had any strong effect on immersion. For better results avatar should be combined with other game elements e.g. story. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2015.
Author Keywords: Avatar; Character; Course design; Game elements; Gamification
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Computers; Avatar; Character; Course design; Game elements; Gamification; Curricula

Authors: Lukosch H.
Author full names: Lukosch, Heide (34977131800)
Title: Balancing fidelity of simulation game environments to increase situational awareness skills
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Delft University of Technology, Jaffalaan 5, GA Delft, 2600, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Lukosch H., Delft University of Technology, Jaffalaan 5, GA Delft, 2600, Netherlands
Abstract: Many working tasks in our complex, technology-based world require active participation in a joint action. Communication and cooperation are basic skills needed for a well functioning team, especially in safety-critical domains like security. In this domain, the ability of a team to cooperate sometimes even decides about life and death. The development of situational awareness and understanding is seen as a prerequisite for effective teamwork. Traditional methods of enhancing teamwork related skills are limited due to their lack of flexibility and their distance to real world challenges. The study aims at exploring whether and how a simulation game should be designed in terms of fidelity to support situational awareness training. Results from usability tests show that realistic virtual environments imply the ability to foster teamwork related skills like situational awareness and communication. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2014.
Index Keywords: Simulation games; Situational awareness
References: Kriz W., Creating effective learning environments and learning organizations through gaming simulation design, Simul. Authors: Aljanaki A.; Bountouridis D.; Burgoyne J.A.; Van Balen J.; Wiering F.; Honing H.; Veltkamp R.
Author full names: Aljanaki, Anna (56410808700); Bountouridis, Dimitrios (36607463900); Burgoyne, John Ashley (23007865600); Van Balen, Jan (55874307000); Wiering, Frans (8976178100); Honing, Henkjan (6603233047); Veltkamp, Remco (7003421646)
Title: Designing games with a purpose for data collection in music research. emotify and hooked: Two case studies
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Utrecht University, Princetonplein 5, Utrecht, 3508 TB, Netherlands; University of Amsterdam, Science Park 105, Amsterdam, 1098 XG, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Aljanaki A., Utrecht University, Princetonplein 5, Utrecht, 3508 TB, Netherlands; Bountouridis D., Utrecht University, Princetonplein 5, Utrecht, 3508 TB, Netherlands; Burgoyne J.A., University of Amsterdam, Science Park 105, Amsterdam, 1098 XG, Netherlands; Van Balen J., Utrecht University, Princetonplein 5, Utrecht, 3508 TB, Netherlands; Wiering F., Utrecht University, Princetonplein 5, Utrecht, 3508 TB, Netherlands; Honing H., University of Amsterdam, Science Park 105, Amsterdam, 1098 XG, Netherlands; Veltkamp R., Utrecht University, Princetonplein 5, Utrecht, 3508 TB, Netherlands
Abstract: Collecting ground truth data for music research requires large amounts of time and money. To avoid these costs, researchers are now trying to collect information through online multiplayer games with the underlying purpose of collecting scientific data. In this paper we present two case studies of such games created for data collection in music information retrieval (MIR): Emotify, for emotional annotation of music, and Hooked, for studying musical catchiness. In addition to the basic requirement of scientific validity, both applications address essential development and design issues, for example, acquiring licensed music or employing popular social frameworks. As such, we hope that they may serve as blueprints for the development of future serious games, not only for music but also for other humanistic domains. The pilot launch of these two games showed that their models are capable of engaging participants and supporting large-scale empirical research. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2014.
Index Keywords: Data collection; Games with a purpose

Authors: da Silva F.S.C.; Vieira L.C.; Bandini S.
Author full names: da Silva, Flávio S. Correa (57192899405); Vieira, Luiz Carlos (57189493844); Bandini, Stefania (7006507839)
Title: Engagement mechanisms for social machines
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: LIDET, University of São Paulo, São Paulo, Brazil; CSAI, University of Milano-Bicocca, Milan, Italy; RCAST, University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: da Silva F.S.C., LIDET, University of São Paulo, São Paulo, Brazil; Vieira L.C., LIDET, University of São Paulo, São Paulo, Brazil; Bandini S., CSAI, University of Milano-Bicocca, Milan, Italy, RCAST, University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Social machines are systems in which humans and computational agents work together. In order to create an effective social machine, one needs to design interaction protocols for agents to collaborate, program the computational agents and build mechanisms to engage humans into activities that are supportive to the goals of the machine. One approach to build engagement is to create opportunities for the experience of fun. The present work contains a discussion about how to design engaging and productive activities for social machines based on fun. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2016.
Author Keywords: Engagement mechanisms; Fun; Interaction models; Social machines
Index Keywords: Computer science; Computers; Computational agents; Inter-action protocols; Interaction model; Artificial intelligence

Authors: Baek S.; Park J.-Y.; Han J.H.
Author full names: Baek, Seungho (56599717300); Park, Ji-Young (56683411700); Han, Jung Hyun (8331337100)
Title: Simulation-based serious games for science education in elementary and middle schools
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Korea University, Seoul, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Baek S., Korea University, Seoul, South Korea; Park J.-Y., Korea University, Seoul, South Korea; Han J.H., Korea University, Seoul, South Korea
Abstract: This paper presents serious games developed for the science subject in elementary and middle schools, specifically for the chapters of “Force and Motion” and “State Change of Water.” The components of each chapter were thoroughly analyzed, and then a game-based curriculum was developed for the components classified as having highor mid-level difficulties in both teaching and learning. Based on the curriculum, the PC-based game “Force and Motion” implemented frictional/gravitational/magnetic force simulations, and the mobile game “State Change of Water” implemented particle-based fluid simulations. The games were evaluated by elementary and middle school teachers, and the evaluation results showed that simulation-based serious games are promising tools for improving the learning effects in science subject. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2016.
Author Keywords: Science education; Serious games; Simulation
Index Keywords: Curricula; Elementary and middle schools; Evaluation results; Fluid simulations; Learning effects; Science education; Serious games; Simulation; Teaching and learning; Teaching

Authors: Riccadonna A.; Gadia D.; Maggiorini D.; Ripamonti L.A.
Author full names: Riccadonna, Alessandro (57496040100); Gadia, Davide (8638291800); Maggiorini, Dario (6508104868); Ripamonti, Laura Anna (6603032354)
Title: N.O.T.E.: Note over the edge
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Università degli Studi di Milano, Via Comelico 39, Milano, 20135, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Riccadonna A., Università degli Studi di Milano, Via Comelico 39, Milano, 20135, Italy; Gadia D., Università degli Studi di Milano, Via Comelico 39, Milano, 20135, Italy; Maggiorini D., Università degli Studi di Milano, Via Comelico 39, Milano, 20135, Italy; Ripamonti L.A., Università degli Studi di Milano, Via Comelico 39, Milano, 20135, Italy
Abstract: A cochlear implant is an electronic device surgically implanted to improve auditory perception in people suffering of severe hearing loss. While a cochlear implant supports a sufficient spoken communication, it is limited in the reception of more complex sounds. Long training sessions are needed in order to enhance the auditory abilities of the patients and, as a consequence, maintain a high level of interest and concentration during the training tasks is mandatory. In this paper, we present N.O.T.E. (Note Over The Edge): a video game designed for auditory training of prelingually deaf children with cochlear implant. N.O.T.E. has been designed as an integrated and flexible system, using a game-based approach to present to the children a set of tests with different complexity, and allowing to the therapist a complete monitoring of the progresses of the training. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2016.
Author Keywords: Auditory training; Children; Cochlear implant; Video game

Authors: Daggett M.; O’Brien K.; Hurley M.
Author full names: Daggett, Matthew (56887401000); O’Brien, Kyle (57190064233); Hurley, Michael (7103181249)
Title: An information theoretic approach for measuring data discovery and utilization during analytical and decision-making processes
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Massachusetts Institute of Technology Lincoln Laboratory, 244 Wood Street, Lexington, 02420, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Daggett M., Massachusetts Institute of Technology Lincoln Laboratory, 244 Wood Street, Lexington, 02420, MA, United States; O’Brien K., Massachusetts Institute of Technology Lincoln Laboratory, 244 Wood Street, Lexington, 02420, MA, United States; Hurley M., Massachusetts Institute of Technology Lincoln Laboratory, 244 Wood Street, Lexington, 02420, MA, United States
Abstract: Across many commercial, government, and military environments, multi-level decision-making processes rely on complex sociotechnical systems. Human dynamics are a significant driver of the overall effectiveness of these processes, yet the characterization of both the intraand inter-individual performance contribution is limited by sparse, qualitative, and often subjective observations. Recent advances in quantitative human-machine instrumentation have made possible greater objective study of users interacting with data; however, performance metrics leveraging these measurements are often narrow and ad hoc. When assessing the analytical and decision-making performance of teams, it is critical to know the information that members have observed, synthesized, and acted upon, and ad hoc approaches can be insufficient. In this paper we present a novel assessment framework based on the principles of Shannon information theory. We detail how this framework can holistically characterize decision information flows and describe its application to assess teams’ abilities to effectively discover data during serious games. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2016.
Index Keywords: Information theory; Complex sociotechnical systems; Decision making process; Individual performance; Information-theoretic approach; Military environment; Multi-level decisions; Overall effectiveness; Shannon information theory; Decision making

Authors: Patiño A.; Romero M.
Author full names: Patiño, Azeneth (56938364900); Romero, Margarida (36698221700)
Title: Identifying pedagogical uses of serious games for learning English as a second language
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Université Laval, 2320 rue des Bibliothèques, Québec, G1V 0A6, QC, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Patiño A., Université Laval, 2320 rue des Bibliothèques, Québec, G1V 0A6, QC, Canada; Romero M., Université Laval, 2320 rue des Bibliothèques, Québec, G1V 0A6, QC, Canada
Abstract: Nowadays, English is a global language taught as a second language in most of non-English speaking countries. Over recent decades, Computer Assisted Language Learning (CALL) has evolved into solutions that allow a higher learner engagement in authentic active-based learning activities. In this context, the educational digital games, also known as Serious Games (SG), allow learning English as a Second Language (ESL) in a playful and engaging environment. In this study, we develop a literature review on the current uses of SG in the context of CALL, in general, and ESL, specifically, in order to create a taxonomy of pedagogical uses of SG for ESL. The taxonomy could be of utility for teachers aiming to integrate SG in their ESL courses. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2015.

Authors: Fritsch M.; Müeller-Feuerstein S.; Groß R.
Author full names: Fritsch, Martin (56410509100); Müeller-Feuerstein, Sascha (56410809300); Groß, Rainer (56410354400)
Title: Combi Nation: The Fusion of Serious Gaming and Cobit
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Ansbach University of Applied Sciences, Residenzstrasse 8, Ansbach, 91522, Germany; Georg Simon Ohm University of Applied Sciences, Kesslerplatz 12, Nuremberg, 90489, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Fritsch M., Ansbach University of Applied Sciences, Residenzstrasse 8, Ansbach, 91522, Germany; Müeller-Feuerstein S., Ansbach University of Applied Sciences, Residenzstrasse 8, Ansbach, 91522, Germany; Groß R., Georg Simon Ohm University of Applied Sciences, Kesslerplatz 12, Nuremberg, 90489, Germany
Abstract: This paper describes the conceptual development and prototypical implementation of a business simulation for the IT governance framework COBIT. In the first part the concept of serious games will be explained and the benefits and challenges of a simulation developed this way will be shown. The second part illustrates IT governance and the structures of COBIT. In the third part the contents for the COBIT simulation are selected and transferred into an optimized simulation model. The paper concludes with an overview of the conceptual development process of the business simulation and the technical implementation of an early staged prototype. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2014.

Authors: Romero M.; Barma S.
Author full names: Romero, Margarida (36698221700); Barma, Sylvie (36863175400)
Title: Serious games opportunities for the primary education curriculum in Quebec
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Université Laval, 2320 rue des Bibliothèques, G1V 0A6, QC, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Romero M., Université Laval, 2320 rue des Bibliothèques, G1V 0A6, QC, Canada; Barma S., Université Laval, 2320 rue des Bibliothèques, G1V 0A6, QC, Canada
Abstract: Curriculum integration is one of the main factors in the teachers’ decision-making process when deciding to use games in formal educational contexts. Based on this observation, we aim to provide primary education teachers with a selection of (serious) games in each of the main areas of the primary education curriculum in Quebec. The taxonomy of the games selected includes Serious Games (SG), designed for educational purposes from the start, but also repurposed games, which, despite not having being intentionally designed for educational purposes, could be diverted for meeting the curriculum objectives of primary education. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2015.

Authors: Klimmt C.; Ogbazion S.
Author full names: Klimmt, Christoph (57203143023); Ogbazion, Semhar (57190061922)
Title: Interesting, but not necessarily effective: Testing a serious game with socially disadvantaged children
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Department of Journalism and Communication Research, Hanover University of Music, Drama, and Media, Expo Plaza 12, Hanover, 30539, Germany; Department of Communication, University of Münster, Bispinghof 9-14, Münster, 48143, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Klimmt C., Department of Journalism and Communication Research, Hanover University of Music, Drama, and Media, Expo Plaza 12, Hanover, 30539, Germany; Ogbazion S., Department of Communication, University of Münster, Bispinghof 9-14, Münster, 48143, Germany
Abstract: Serious games are often hoped to outperform conventional instruction techniques particularly in educationally challenging contexts. The present study tested a German serious game designed to teach fundamentals of civic engagement with a class of elementary school children (N = 26, mean age 10 years) from a socially disadvantaged urban population. Findings suggest that the young players liked the new mode of learning, but effects of playing on domain knowledge were not observed. We discuss the results with regard to the preconditions that serious games have to meet just as conventional instruction techniques when players/learners are facing specific challenges such as social disadvantages. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2016.

Authors: Arnab S.; Ger P.M.; Lim T.; Lameras P.; Hendrix M.; Kiili K.; Hauge J.B.; Ninaus M.; de Freitas S.; Mazzetti A.; Dahlbom A.; Degano C.; Stanescu I.; Riveiro M.
Author full names: Arnab, Sylvester (24528279500); Ger, Pablo Moreno (8951372100); Lim, Theodore (24923001300); Lameras, Petros (37561547200); Hendrix, Maurice (23466949700); Kiili, Kristian (8304180400); Hauge, Jannicke Baalsrud (16233132400); Ninaus, Manuel (55797096600); de Freitas, Sara (57203045925); Mazzetti, Alessandro (37017635000); Dahlbom, Anders (24722525400); Degano, Cristiana (6602277633); Stanescu, Ioana (35280492300); Riveiro, Maria (23036406500)
Title: A conceptual model towards the scaffolding of learning experience
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Disruptive Media Learning Lab, Coventry University, Coventry, United Kingdom; Universidad Complutense de Madrid, Madrid, 28040, Spain; Herriot-Watt University, Edinburgh, EH14 5SJ, United Kingdom; Serious Games Institute, Coventry University, Coventry, United Kingdom; School of Science and Technology, University of Northampton, Northampton, NN2 6JB, United Kingdom; Tampere University of Technology, P.O. Box 300, Pori, 28101, Finland; Hauge J.B., Bremer Institut für Produktion und Logistik, Hochschulring 20, Bremen, 28359, Germany; Ninaus M., University of Graz, Universitätsplatz 2/III, Graz, 8010, Austria; de Freitas S., Curtin University, Kent St, Bentley, 6102, WA, Australia; Mazzetti A., Gruppo SIGLA S.r.l, Via Finocchiaro Aprile 31, Genoa, 16129, Italy; Dahlbom A., Högskolan i Skövde, Box 408, Skövde, 541 28, Sweden; Degano C., Gruppo SIGLA S.r.l, Via Finocchiaro Aprile 31, Genoa, 16129, Italy; Stanescu I., “Carol I” National Defence University, 68-72 Panduri Street, Bucharest, Romania; Riveiro M., Högskolan i Skövde, Box 408, Skövde, 541 28, Sweden
Abstract: The challenge of delivering personalized learning experiences is amplified by the size of classrooms and of online learning communities. In turn, serious games are increasingly recognized for their potential to improve education, but a typical requirement from instructors is to gain insight into how the students are playing. When we bring games into the rapidly growing online learning communities, the challenges multiply and hinder the potential effectiveness of serious games. There is a need to deliver a comprehensive, flexible and intelligent learning framework that facilitates better understanding of learners’ knowledge, effective assessment of their progress and continuous evaluation and optimization of the environments in which they learn. This paper aims to explore the potential in the use of games and learning analytics towards scaffolding and supporting teaching and learning experience. The conceptual model discussed aims to highlight key considerations that may advance the current state of learning analytics, adaptive learning and serious games, by leveraging serious games as an ideal medium for gathering data and performing adaptations. This opportunity has the potential to affect the design and deployment of education and training in the future. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2015.
Index Keywords: Education computing; Scaffolds; Social networking (online); Teaching; Adaptive learning; Conceptual model; Education and training; Intelligent learning; Learning experiences; Online learning community; Personalized learning; Teaching and learning; E-learning

Authors: Becker J.; van Lankveld G.; Steiner C.; Hemmje M.
Author full names: Becker, Jana (57190074049); van Lankveld, Giel (36134136600); Steiner, Christina (14632750000); Hemmje, Matthias (55979769600)
Title: Realizing an applied gaming ecosystem: Towards supporting service-based innovation knowledge management and transfer
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Research Institute for Telecommunication and Cooperation, Martin-Schmeisser-Weg 4, Dortmund, 44227, Germany; Open University of the Netherlands, Valkenburgerweg 177, Heerlen, 6419 AT, Netherlands; Graz University of Technology, Inffeldgasse 13, Graz, 8010, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Becker J., Research Institute for Telecommunication and Cooperation, Martin-Schmeisser-Weg 4, Dortmund, 44227, Germany; van Lankveld G., Open University of the Netherlands, Valkenburgerweg 177, Heerlen, 6419 AT, Netherlands; Steiner C., Graz University of Technology, Inffeldgasse 13, Graz, 8010, Austria; Hemmje M., Research Institute for Telecommunication and Cooperation, Martin-Schmeisser-Weg 4, Dortmund, 44227, Germany
Abstract: The EU-based industry for non-leisure games is an emerging business. As such it is still fragmented and needs to achieve critical mass to compete globally. Nevertheless its growth potential is widely recognized. To become competitive the relevant applied gaming communities and SMEs require support by fostering the generation of innovation potential. The European project Realizing an Applied Gaming Ecosystem (RAGE) is aiming at supporting this challenge. RAGE will help by making available an interoperable set of advanced technology assets, tuned to applied gaming, as well as proven practices of using asset-based applied games in various real-world contexts, and finally a centralized access to a wide range of applied gaming software modules, services and related document, media, and educational resources within an online community portal called the RAGE Ecosystem. It is based on an integrational, user-centered approach of Knowledge Management and Innovation Processes in the shape of a service-based implementation. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2016.
Index Keywords: Ecology; Ecosystems; Electronic document exchange; Interoperability; Advanced technology; Educational resource; European project; Growth potential; Innovation potential; Innovation process; On-line communities; User-centered approach; Knowledge management

Authors: Göbl B.; Hlavacs H.; Hofer J.; Müller I.; Müllner H.; Schubert C.; Spallek H.; Rybka C.; Sprung M.
Author full names: Göbl, Barbara (57190066628); Hlavacs, Helmut (6506041648); Hofer, Jessica (57190072410); Müller, Isabelle (56937917700); Müllner, Hélen (57190065685); Schubert, Claudia (57190064448); Spallek, Halina (57190071904); Rybka, Charlotte (57190071899); Sprung, Manuel (59578288200)
Title: Mindspace: Treating anxiety disorders in children with a CBT game
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Research Group Entertainment Computing, University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria; Faculty of Psychology, University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Göbl B., Research Group Entertainment Computing, University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria; Hlavacs H., Research Group Entertainment Computing, University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria; Hofer J., Faculty of Psychology, University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria; Müller I., Faculty of Psychology, University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria; Müllner H., Faculty of Psychology, University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria; Schubert C., Faculty of Psychology, University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria; Spallek H., Faculty of Psychology, University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria; Rybka C., Faculty of Psychology, University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria; Sprung M., Faculty of Psychology, University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria
Abstract: We describe the design process and implementation of the serious game MindSpace. MindSpace provides a playful setting for treating children with a variety of social and specific anxiety disorders. A modular approach is explained, taking a closer look on cognitive-behavioral techniques such as exposure tasks, psycho-education or coping techniques and how they are implemented within a game setting. Also, special focus is paid to the needs of our target group by putting a strong emphasis on usability and motivational factors and hence, therapy adherence. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2016.
Index Keywords: Computer science; Computers; Design process; Modular approach; Serious games; Target group; Artificial intelligence

Authors: Boyle J.; Boyle E.A.
Author full names: Boyle, James (7401974442); Boyle, Elizabeth A. (36503450400)
Title: Towards an understanding of the relationship between executive functions and learning outcomes from serious computer games
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: School of Psychological Sciences and Health, University of Strathclyde, 40 George Street, Glasgow, G1 1QE, United Kingdom; School of Social Sciences, University of the West of Scotland, High Street, Paisley, PA1 2BE, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Boyle J., School of Psychological Sciences and Health, University of Strathclyde, 40 George Street, Glasgow, G1 1QE, United Kingdom; Boyle E.A., School of Social Sciences, University of the West of Scotland, High Street, Paisley, PA1 2BE, United Kingdom
Abstract: There is accumulating evidence that playing games leads to a range of cognitive and perceptual advantages. In addition there has been speculation that digital games can support higher level thinking. In this paper we propose that viewing these gains from the perspective of executive functions can help to provide a more coherent approach to understanding the cognitive benefits of playing games. Executive functions refer to a range of higher level cognitive processes that regulate, control and manage other cognitive processes. Three models are considered: Baddeley’s model of working memory [1], and two models of executive functions, that of Anderson [2], and that of Diamond [3]. The implications for serious games research and games design and for future research are considered. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2014
Index Keywords: Executive function; Learning outcome
